posts.author: Alistair Tweedale
posts.title: Manchester City's season fell apart this time last year. Are they better prepared to challenge this time around?
posts.text:
Alistair Tweedale 3 October 2017 • 11:53am 
T here is no doubt this is a very different Manchester City side to the team of one year ago: a £220million spending spree would do that to you. 
Much-changed personnel now combine with those who managed to remain in Pep Guardiola's plans and are understandably significantly better-schooled in his teachings 12 months down the line. 
But City are now only one point better off than they were after seven games in 2016/17; it was at this stage last season that their title challenge fell apart, starting with a 2-0 defeat at Tottenham on Oct 2 . Prior to that loss City had won six from six, giving them an even better record than they had at the same stage this season. 
What followed was a huge shock. City drew three of their next four games, and lost three more times in December to leave them fifth at the turn of the year, having been four points clear at the top and looking a good bet for the title after six matches. 
Any similar capitulation would be similarly shocking this time around, but are they now better equipped to maintain a proper title challenge? Pep's team crumbled at White Hart Lane this time last season in what was the start of a terrible run of results Credit: EPA 
B esides having removed much of the deadwood from the squad and strengthened individuals in more areas than many clubs could dream of, City are now a better collective than they were a year ago. 
Roughly speaking, they have faced a similar level of opposition in their first seven games this season compared to last. 
Both times they have played two of the other 'big six' sides in their first seven games, though the crucial difference this season has been the convincing nature with which they saw off both Liverpool and Chelsea , where last season they impressed in winning at Old Trafford but crumbled meekly away to Spurs, and the statistics bear out proof that they are now a much-improved side. Manchester City first seven games | Premier League 
C ity are retaining possession better than they were a year ago, with around 69 per cent possession compared to 63 per cent last season and 89 per cent passing accuracy, up from 84 per cent. 
They are doing more with that possession, having had 101 shots in seven games in 2017/18 compared to 85 at this stage last season. They are hitting the target and scoring with roughly the same efficiency, and having had more attempts they have therefore scored more. 
With marauding full-backs that Pep is now much happier with , and flying, speedy, tricky wingers, City stretch the play and constantly get the ball into dangerous, wide positions high up the pitch, as was seen to devastating effect at Chelsea over the weekend. 
The cohesion with which their attack now plays has produced staggering results, and the individual is now far less important than the collective. Attempted dribbles by City players are down 31 per cent on this time last season (121 down from 176), but the wide players - traditionally those you would expect to find dribbling - still retain real value. Man City's first 7 games performance 
C ity have attempted 122 crosses in open play this season - nearly double the 66 they had put in at this stage last term - while they have scored four goals from crosses in open play this season, where a year ago they hadn't scored any. 
While the attacking changes have been stark, there have been crucial changes at the other end, too. 
City have conceded only two goals so far this season, where a year ago they had shipped seven, but it isn't just the upgrade from Claudio Bravo to Ederson between the sticks that has had a significant effect. 
Their defenders are being pulled out of position less often, and are therefore being forced into fewer 'defensive actions' such as tackles and interceptions. The best defenders allowing their reading of the game and positioning to do the hard work, and that is increasingly the case for Nicolas Otamendi and John Stones in what is a noticeably more organised team. John Stones has made an impressive start to the season Credit: Getty images 
A major consequence of this is that City's players have committed only three errors leading to opposition chances this season, compared to six at the same stage last season. Stones looks like he could develop Under Guardiola into the defender he has long suggested he could one day be. 
So, is this a team that can challenge? 
The early signs certainly suggest City are markedly stronger than they were a year ago, but nobody expected last season's collapse and Pep Guardiola will remain wary despite increased confidence in his players. 
They may now an even greater number of incredible individuals but, crucially, the collective Manchester City now amounts to far more than they did a season ago. A genuine title tilt is considerably more likely this time around. Related Topics

posts.author: Paul Hayward
posts.title: FA draws total blank in bid to make contact with gay professional footballers
posts.text:
T he Football Association’s attempts to make contact with gay professional footballers have drawn a blank, with “not one” willing to meet the organisation’s chairman, Greg Clarke, even in secret or anonymously.
On his tour of the national game, Clarke managed to speak to a black manager who said people in football from his ethnic background could “forget” about being hired if they earned a reputation for being “difficult”.
Race proved an easier subject for the FA chairman to discuss than sexuality, with current non-heterosexual players in the men’s professional game preferring not to be open about their sexuality in a sport where there is thought to be a higher than average chance of hostility or derision.
Clarke told Telegraph Sport : “I understand the reticence. I went to the women’s cup final. It was great. There was gay, there was straight, there were kids, it was relaxed. It was like a big wedding reception. I had a great time. There was no judgment in the room. Everyone was there because they wanted to see the game.
“ I’ve met a lot of gay activists , gay publishers. I went down to Stonewall, watched a game, had a beer in the bar afterwards - and talked about the issues. At the semi-pro level and below, nobody’s worried. I haven’t met one player at professional level who would even agree to meet me in the middle of nowhere for a conversation over a cup of coffee. Not one.
Greg Clarke says he understands the reticence of people to speak out Credit: getty images “I don’t blame them for that. If they don’t feel comfortable having that conversation, it doesn’t say good things about our game.”
C larke insisted he is not assuming this reluctance stems from a fear of abuse from some fans and on social media, the most commonly posited reasons for not ‘coming out’. He said: “I don’t want to speculate about what’s in their heads. They obviously don’t feel comfortable. I’ve spoken to the Premier League, the EFL [English Football League], the PFA [Professional Footballers’ Association], the LMA [League Managers’ Association].
“We are all desperate to make the game more LGBT-inclusive. We haven’t yet won the trust of the professional gay players. I’ve reached out. I’ve seen athletes, swimmers, divers, I’ve gone everywhere. And they’ve shared their views with me. I’ve said, ‘Why won’t gay footballers meet me?’. They’ve all said, ‘I don’t know because I don’t know any gay footballers’. They’re very deeply buried.”
At professional level, Thomas Hitzlsperger (Aston Villa and West Ham) and Robbie Rogers (Leeds United) have both spoken of their homosexuality, but only after leaving the English game or retiring. In May, Liam Davis became the first openly gay footballer to play at Wembley, in the FA Vase final.
Thomas Hitzlsperger is one of very few footballers to have spoken openly about their sexuality Credit: pa C larke says he has also tried to break down barriers for black coaches and managers, and heard an alarming claim that “awkward” individuals in that field are more likely to suffer consequences.
“When I had the same conversation with black managers, BAME managers [about problems faced], I ended up in a situation where I was meeting clandestinely with black players and black managers,” Clarke said. “I was in a coffee bar talking to a really nice guy who’s a black manager and he said, ‘Let me tell you something, Greg. It’s really hard to get a job as a manager. It’s doubly hard to get a job as a black manager. But if you’re an awkward black manager - forget it. We can’t get a reputation for being difficult’.
“I’m not going to say who they were. All the black managers and players I met years ago when I was putting the Rooney rule [on job interview ratios] in place - I never said a word about any of them.”
Clarke accepted that gay footballers were under no obligation to reveal their sexuality. He said: “Why would you sign up for that potential risk if it’s working for you, if you’re happy? You might think, ‘Why do I need to share my sexuality with anybody?’. I respect that. Where I worry is that there may be people who want to be openly gay but don’t feel able to be openly gay. If they do, they should be comfortable, accepted and supported.”

Match of the Day commentator Guy Mowbray was talking about Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge's impressive goalscoring record against the Tyneside club during coverage of their game at St James' Park on Sunday afternoon.

posts.author: Ashley Armstrong
posts.title: Greggs still on a roll as breakfast options boost sales
posts.text:
S ales at Greggs, the bakery chain best known for its sausage rolls and steak bakes, have been boosted by the addition of healthy salads and breakfast options despite the company raising prices in the face of increasing costs.
Total sales, including its franchise shops, rose by 7.8pc during the 13 weeks to September 30 while like-for-like sales increased by 3.9pc during the period.
Roger Whiteside, chief executive, last month announced an ambition to have more than 2,000 shops across the UK, despite concerns about weakening consumer spending. During the period Greggs opened 98 new shops and closed 32, taking its total to 1,830 across the UK, far beyond the number of Starbucks cafes in the UK.
The company said that sales of its breakfast options, which include bacon rolls and porridge pots, continued to grow strongly and it would be shortly adding a new "all day breakfast wrap" and expanding its "Balanced Choice" range.
Healthy options now make up more than 10pc of the high street baker's sales although sausage rolls remain its best-selling item.
Roger Whiteside, Greggs chief executive "Increasing like-for-like sales, plus the planned addition of around 100 net new shops this year means Greggs has got all the ingredients of an attractive roll-out story," said George Salmon, analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown.
"It’s good to see the group investing to ensure its menu doesn’t become stale, too. New breakfast options and balanced choices like Thai Chicken soup are gaining increasing popularity with customers, and are a step forward as the country becomes ever more health-conscious."
G reggs' fans were outraged last month when the price of its ubiquitous sausage roll rose from 85p to 90p while its breakfast meal deal - which includes a sausage and egg roll and a hot drink - also climbed in price from £2 to £2.25.
Roger Whiteside, chief executive , said that there was a "continuous battle between cost inflation and the amount that could be priced in for customers".
"We are a value retailer so we fight tooth and nail to limit it as much as possible and we have been successful for a number of years but this year we have been pressured by ingredient inflation and wage rises, so costs have been higher than normal."

posts.title: Jacob Rees-Mogg compares Brexit to battles of Agincourt, Waterloo and Trafalgar
posts.text:
Jack Maidment , Political Correspondent 3 October 2017 • 11:50am 
J acob Rees-Mogg has compared the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union to the battles of Agincourt, Waterloo and Trafalgar as he insisted young people will “love” Brexit. 
The leading Eurosceptic said the UK’s divorce from Brussels would be a similarly important moment in British history as he also suggested its significance would match the signing of the Magna Carta. 
Mr Rees-Mogg also claimed younger generations would welcome Brexit when they realise it means they will be in charge of their own future rather than having their lives “determined” by Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission. 
Mr Rees-Mogg has been a box office attraction at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester with activists willing to brave lengthy queues for the chance to hear him speak. Jacob Rees-Mogg poses for a photograph outside the Manchester Central Convention Centre Credit: Oli Scarff/AFP 
A ppearing at a fringe event on Monday night, Mr Mogg sought to make a positive case for Brexit, telling a cheering crowd: “We need to be reiterating the benefits of Brexit because this is so important in the history of our country. 
“This is Magna Carta, it’s the Burgesses coming at Parliament, it’s the great reform bill, it;s the bill of rights, it’s Waterloo, it’s Agincourt, it’s Crecy. We win all of these things.” 
Someone in the crowd then yelled “Trafalgar!” prompting Mr Rees-Mogg to add: “And Trafalgar, absolutely.” 
Mr Rees-Mogg said leaving the bloc would free the UK “from a failing economic model” - something he described as a “liberation” and an “inspiration”. 
The MP for North East Somerset said: “We must make those arguments and young people will love it because we will be telling young people that they will determine their lives rather than having them determined for them by Monsieur Juncker. 
“That must seem to me to be a more attractive prospect. Be of good cheer. We won. It is happening. Now what we have got to do is back Theresa May.” Profile | Jacob Rees-Mogg MP 
B ut he said the Conservative Party needed to unite behind Mrs May. 
“Her position needs to remain solid and well supported by all Conservatives to get the Brexit deal done,” he said. 
“No more faffing around about alternatives to Mrs May. She is our leader, she needs our support, she deserves our support.” 
He also praised Boris Johnson for making the positive case for Brexit in recent high profile interventions, including in a 4,000 word article in The Telegraph. 
“The good cheer we get from the Foreign Secretary is fantastic,” he said. 
“It is a tonic. It is not just a tonic, it’s a gin and tonic to our spirits.” Related Topics

posts.title: Chess player banned by Iran for not wearing a hijab switches to US
posts.text:
Leon Watson 3 October 2017 • 11:46am 
A chess player banned from the Iranian national women's team for attending an international competition without wearing an Islamic headscarf has joined the US team. 
Dorsa Derakhshani refused to wear the headscarf, known as the hijab, during the Tradewise Gibraltar Chess tournament in February, and joined the U.S. national team. 
Since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, Iran has required women to wear the hijab in public places. Dorsa Derakhshani,Iranian #chess champion expelled from national team for not wearing the veil. #ForcedHijab pic.twitter.com/IAZxiCmcdq — Darya Safai (@SafaiDarya) February 20, 2017 
D orsa's registration has been altered on the world governing body Fide's website and the switch to the United States Chess Federation confirmed by the president of Iran's chess federation, Mehrdad Pahlevanzadeh. 
Pahlevanzadeh added that she was not a member of Iran's national chess team. "She played for Iran only one time in 2014," he clarified. 
Dorsa left Tehran and moved to Barcelona in 2015 after she received an invitation by a chess club that also supported her studies, according to ISNA. Kirsan Ilyumzhinov (L), president of the world chess body Fide, watches winner Tan Zhongyi of China (C) and second-placed Anna Muzychuk (R) of Ukraine with their trophies after their Women's World Chess Championship final in Tehran, Iran Credit: EPA/STRINGER 
S he was awarded the titles Woman Grandmaster and International Master by the World Chess Federation in 2016. 
At the February competition in Gibraltar, her brother Borna Derakhshani, also a chess player, was paired up by a computer against Israeli grandmaster Alexander Huzman. 
Pahlevanzadeh later announced that Borna was banned from playing for Iran, and that Dorsa was also banned for not wearing the hijab at that competition. Chess | FIDE’s stance on tackling discrimination 
I ran has a policy of not competing against Israeli athletes. The country does not recognize Israel and supports anti-Israeli militant groups like Hamas and Hezbollah. 
Shohreh Bayat, the general secretary of Iran's chess federation, said Dorsa was now studying in the U.S., according to Tasnim, another semi-official Iranian news agency. 
"(Dorsa) Derakhshani has not become a member of the U.S. national chess team, she just changed her federation to the United States," Bayat said. Nazi Paikidze Credit: ZUMA Press, Inc. / Alamy Stock Photo 
D orsa will join Nazi Paikidze-Barnes, the former US champion, who refused to participate in the Women’s World Chess Championship held in Tehran, Iran, in February to protest against the country’s hijab law that makes it mandatory for all women to wear hijab in public places. 
“I think it’s unacceptable to host a WOMEN’S World Championship in a place where women do not have basic fundamental rights and are treated as second-class citizens. 
"For those saying that I don't know anything about Iran: I have received the most support and gratitude from the people of Iran, who are facing this situation every day,” Paikidze wrote in an Instagram post in September 2016.

S outh Africa's audit regulator has fast-tracked its probe into KPMG over the work it did with the controversial billionaire Gupta family, who are accused of buying influence with President Jacob Zuma. 
The boss of the Independent Regulatory Board for Auditors' (IRBA) Bernard Agulhas reportedly told parliament in Cape Town on Tuesday that the agency did not always get the information it needed from the accounting giant at the start of its probe, although KPMG has since cooperated. 
"We will fast-track the investigation, but we have to respect the prescribed process of the auditing profession act and disciplinary rules," he added. 
IRBA's inquiry follows an internal investigation at the business which found that the work it did for companies owned by the Gupta family "fell considerably short" of standards , leading to a clear out of management in its South African division. 
The growing scandal has forced some clients to consider dumping the firm as its auditor, although sources have told Reuters that the central bank was urging top lenders not to fire KPMG because doing so could undermine financial stability. 
A KPMG spokesman said the firm is complying with all of IRBA’s requests for documents.

3 October 2017 • 12:17pm Mary Price writes 
W e would like to spend three days in Spain’s Picos de Europa in June 2018. We don’t want to hire a car; can you suggest a way to get there, and accommodation that would give us reasonable access to some nice easy walking? We will probably base ourselves for the rest of the holiday in Santander and San Sebastián. The Picos de Europa are scandalously overlooked by most UK travellers Credit: ©pintxoman - stock.adobe.com Isabella Noble, Spain expert, replies 
In July and August, summer buses whizz hikers up to several lovely walks within the Picos de Europa national park. In June, however, you’ll be dependent on taxis to get you from your base. 
From Santander, the nearest part of the Picos is the eastern, Cantabrian side; and the main access town is attractive cobbled Potes in the Liébana valley. Direct buses link Santander and Potes. 
There are lovely walks for all levels of ability from the top of the Fuente Dé cable car (a 30-minute/£25 taxi ride west from Potes) and from hamlets along the CA185 road between Potes and Fuente Dé. In July and August, summer buses whizz hikers up to several lovely walks within the Picos de Europa national park Credit: ©antonel - stock.adobe.com 
Hotel del Oso in tiny Cosgaya has a terrific restaurant ( hoteldeloso.com ; double rooms cost from £85 B&B), more rustic is riverside Casa Cayo in Potes ( casacayo.com ; double rooms from £46). 
Alternatively, if you are happy to consider flying into Asturias airport, you could explore the northern and western Picos, home to the park’s most dramatic walks. 
The best base (accessible by bus from Asturias airport with a change in Oviedo) is bustling Cangas de Onís. Here, Hotel Nochendi, with an excellent Asturian restaurant, is the best place to stay (00 34 985 891643; double room £70 B&B). 
For walks, Cangas taxis can take you to the Covadonga lakes (one-way £25), and Cangas Aventura runs drop-off/ pickup services for the spectacular six-mile-long Garganta del Cares gorge ( cangasaventura.com ; £32 per person round-trip). posts.title: New flights from Qatar to Cardiff: stroke of genius or utter folly?
posts.text:
Oliver Smith , Digital Travel Editor 3 October 2017 • 12:03pm 
F un-loving, down-to-earth Cardiff couldn’t be more different from futuristic, oil-rich Doha. But from May 2018, the two cities will be linked with a daily flight, courtesy of Qatar Airways. 
Do the rugby-mad residents of the Welsh capital long to explore the souks and skyscrapers of Doha? Are Qatari businesses itching to invest in South Wales? The chief executive of Qatar Airways (Akbar Al Bakerm) thinks so – but is facing stern opposition from inside his own company. At a glance | Cardiff v Doha 
The chief executive this week admitted that he has come under pressure to ditch the plans, with colleagues suggesting the demand simply isn’t there. But he is adamant it will be a success. 
"Wales is a huge developing state,” he told the BBC . “It was important that we operate and connect the people of Wales, and the South West, with the rest of the world.” Cardiff, capital of rugby-loving Wales Credit: ©travelwitness - stock.adobe.com 
He added: "When a child needs a bar of chocolate you don't give it in pieces. The region was longing for an international flight and as one of the world's only five-star airlines, why shouldn't we go daily?" 
The decision to launch the route was made in April, however, before the ongoing dispute between Qatar and its Middle Eastern neighbours, over its alleged support of international terror groups (allegations which are denied by rulers in Doha). Qatar Airways is currently banned from flying to Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Bahrain, and has been banned from entering the airspace of those nations too. That means circuitous routes to dozens of destinations, longer journey times for travellers, and bigger fuel bills. Cerys Matthews: Why Cardiff is Britain's most underrated city 
But Deb Barber, Cardiff Airport’s chief executive, points out that 1.4 million passengers from Wales and the South West already fly to the Middle East each year using other UK airports. 
Should the service prove a success, it wouldn’t be the first time a curious air route has defied the odds. 
A peek at the aviation analyst OAG’s pocket flight guide reveals a whole raft of unlikely cities linked by air. Cardiff’s route map is decidedly unexotic, with nothing beyond mainstream Europe, but Qatar Airways has already made a success of direct flights to Atlanta, Chengdu, Djibouti, Ho Chi Minh City, Kiev, Skopje, Tbilisi and Yerevan (as well as the Uganda town of Entebbe). And if Wizz Air can fill flights from Doncaster to Cluj-Napoca (that’s in Romania), why shouldn’t Cardiff-Doha prove profitable? The Yorkshire airport also has links with Lublin and Katowice in Poland, alongside less surprising destinations like Faro, Amsterdam and Malaga. Liverpool, meanwhile, is connected with Bacau (Romania again) and Nowy Dwor Mazowiecki (Poland). Cluj, Romania Credit: Â©outchill - stock.adobe.com 
Not one but two airlines (Wow Air and Icelandair) compete for passengers between Cleveland, Ohio (nicknamed “the mistake on the lake”), and Reykjavik. Bizarrely, it’s the US city’s only direct connection with Europe. Game of Thrones must be responsible. Reykjavik also has non-stop flights to Baltimore, Edmonton, Pittsburgh and Seattle. Reach Iceland with ease from Ohio Credit: ©eugenesergeev - stock.adobe.com/Eugene Sergeev 
Edinburgh's long-haul links are few and far between, but they do include Hartford, Connecticut. Mark Twain House in Hartford, Connecticut Credit: Credit: Philip Scalia / Alamy Stock Photo/Philip Scalia / Alamy Stock Photo 
And from Cork, there’s just one long-haul service – to, err, Providence, Rhode Island. Explain that one.

posts.title: Stephen Paddock: Who was the Mandalay Bay attacker and what was his motive?
posts.text:
Roland Oliphant 3 October 2017 • 10:41pm 
T he man who killed at least 59 people in the United States worst ever mass shooting was a wealthy property owner and a regular in Las Vegas casinos who made a living through "gambling and speculation," it has been claimed. People carry a person at the Route 91 Harvest country music festival after apparent gunfire Credit: David Becker/Getty Images 
S tephen C Paddock, 64, killed himself before armed police blasted their way into his hotel room on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel in Las Vegas on Sunday night. 
Next to his body, police found an arsenal of weapons including more than ten rifles but no immediate clue telling them what drove him to open fire from his window at concert goers below. Stephen Paddock 
T he Islamic State terror group claimed Paddock converted to Islam a few months ago, through its official Amaq news channel . 
They said the attack, the deadliest mass shooting in US history, was carried out by a “soldier” of the caliphate and was done “in response to calls to target coalition countries.” 
In another statement released hours later, Isil referred to Paddock by the nom de guerre Abu Abd al-Barr al-Amriki and said he answered a call to arms by its leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. 
US officials have said they are examining the claim, but are yet to find any evidence linking the shooter to any organised terrorist group. 
Relatives described Paddock as “just a guy” who was never in a hurry and retired to the Nevada desert to enjoy a dry climate and Las Vegas’s casinos. 
"We can’t understand what happened," a distraught Eric Paddock, Stephen’s brother, told reporters outside his home in Orlando, Florida. 
He said his brother was "not a normal guy" and "played high stakes video poker". He said his brother being named by authorities as the shooting suspect was "like if an asteroid fell out of the sky". 
E ric Paddock says his brother was a multimillionaire who made much of his money investing in real estate. 
He told reporters on Monday in Orlando that his brother was also an accountant for many years. 
He was not aware of his brother having any recent financial difficulties. 
Stephen Paddock recently sent a walking aide by post to his 90-year-old mother. 
The brother says the shooter collected coins when he was a child. Las Vegas gunman's brother: 'It's like an asteroid fell out of the sky' 01:03 
"He’s not an avid gun guy at all. The fact that he had those kind of weapons is just – where the hell did he get automatic weapons? He has no military background or anything like that,” he told MSNBC. 
"He’s just a guy who lived in a house in Mesquite, drove down and gambled in Las Vegas. He did...stuff. Eat burritos." An undated FBI photo of serial bank robber Benjamin Hoskins Paddock, Stephen Paddock's father Credit: Handout/ REUTERS 
T he family grew up in Sun Valley, California, Bruce Paddock, another of his brothers, told NBC. 
Their father, Benjamin Hoskins Paddock, was a career bank robber who was on the FBI's Top Ten Most Wanted list between 1969 and 1977, it was reported. “Not an avid gun guy at all...where the hell did he get automatic weapons? He has no military background,” gunman’s brother says pic.twitter.com/EMSKLQGYFM — CBS News (@CBSNews) October 2, 2017 
S tephen Paddock worked various jobs, including as an auditor at a company that later became Lockheed Martin between 1985-1988. 
Family members told local media he also made a living from renting and managing apartment buildings, and he appears to have owned a string of properties in Florida, Texas, and Nevada. Mandalay Bay hotel shooting 
F ormer neighbours said Paddock had said his main source of income was gambling. 
Don and Sharon Judy, who lived next door to Paddock and his girlfriend, Marilou Danley, when he owned a house in Melbourne, Florida between 2013 and 2015, said he was “very friendly” and “lived by gambling.” Stephen Paddock's brother Eric Paddock said the family was "completely dumbfounded" Credit: John Raoux/AP 
“He was very open about that. He said he traveled all around to his different homes, that he gambled,” Mrs Judy told Florida Today. 
M rs Judy said he had once shown her how he had won $20,000 via online gambling on his smartphone. Mesquite Police Department blocked access to the Sun City Mesquite community where Paddock lived Credit: Gabe Ginsberg/Getty Images North America 
"He said 'Marilou and I that’s what we do for a living, we gamble and we speculate,' she added. 
C iting law enforcement sources, NBC said records showed Paddock had racked up several gambling transactions in the “tens of thousands” of dollars in recent weeks. It was unclear if those were wins or losses. 
P addock moved into a three bedroom, single storey house at the Sun City retirement community in Mesquite, a desert town of about 17,400 people 80 miles northwest of Las Vegas, in 2015. 
Police were searching the home on Monday. 
Neighbours said Paddock and Ms Danley kept themselves to themselves and he does not appear to have had any trouble with the police. Broken windows on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel, where Paddock amassed an arsenal of 20 guns Credit: David Becker/Getty Images 
J oe Lombardo, the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department Sheriff, said local police had nothing more on him than a seven-year old citation, which had been resolved as “a normal practice in the court system." 
Paddock held a pilot’s license, owned two aircraft, and had a permit to hunt in Alaska. He had several legally owned guns, but they do not appear to have been in the arsenal he amassed in his hotel room. People run for cover after Paddock opened fire on the Route 91 Harvest country music festival Credit: David Becker/Getty 
P olice say Paddock checked into the Mandalay Bay hotel last Thursday September 28, but it was unclear how he amassed his huge arsenal of weapons in the room unnoticed. 
Sherriff Lombardo said police had located Ms Danley, who is believed to be from the Philippines, “outside the country” and did not believe she was involved in the shooting. 
“She was not with him when he checked in. We have discovered he was utilizing some of her identification,” he said. 
Ms Danley’s LinkedIn page described her as a “Gambling & Casinos Professional” who worked at the Atlantic Casino Resort Spa in Reno between 2010 and 2013. 
The terrorist group Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant claimed Paddock had acted on its instructions after converting to Islam several months ago. It offered no evidence for the claim. 
The gunman responsible for the worst mass shooting in modern US history is believed to be a grandfather who lived in a remote desert home. Related Topics

Roland Oliphant 3 October 2017 • 12:24pm 
P olice using specialised bomb-hunting robots to search the home of the Mandalay Bay gunman have uncovered a weapons stockpile including explosives, firearms, and thousands of rounds of ammunition. 
Officers had to remove the garage door so a robot could enter Stephen Paddock’s three-bedroom bungalow in Mesquite, 80 miles northwest of Las Vegas , when they raided the house on Monday morning. 
Once the building had been swept for booby traps, heavily armed officers discovered 19 firearms, thousands of rounds of ammunition and several pounds of the powder explosive tannerite. Garage door was removed so a robot could enter the home #LasVegasShooting #Mesquite pic.twitter.com/kVOOW5YD0I — Lucas Thomas (@LucasThomas14) October 2, 2017 
I n his car they also found a quantity of ammonium nitrate, a fertiliser that can be used to create a powerful explosive. 
Tannerite can be bought commercially and used on gun ranges to make targets explode when hit. It was used in the September 2016 New York and New Jersey bombings that injured 35 people. Stephen Paddock bought the home in 2015 Credit: AFP/Getty 
A mmonium nitrate is infamous as a bomb ingredient that has been used by terrorists including the IRA, Al Qaeda, and Oklahoma City bomber Timothy McVey. 
Police did not say whether they believed Paddock planned to use the Tannerite or ammonium nitrate to build bombs. 
Paddock, 64, held a hunting license. 
His brother Eric Paddock although said his brother may have owned a small number of firearms, he “was not an avid gun guy at all.” 
“Where the hell did he get automatic weapons? He has no military background or anything like that,” Eric Paddock told reporters on Monday. Police used a bomb-hinting robot to sweep the property for booby traps Credit: Chris Carlson/AP 
C hris Sullivan, the owner of Guns & Guitars, a firearms shop in Mesquite, issued a statement confirming Paddock was a customer but said he cleared "all necessary background checks and procedures." 
"He never gave any indication or reason to believe he was unstable or unfit at any time," Mr Sullivan said in comments carried by ABC. He did not say how many weapons Paddock bought. 
Paddock, 64, lived in the the bungalow in Sun City, a retirement community clustered around a golf course, for at least nine months. Paddock was a customer at Guns and Guitars, a Mesquite fire arms shop. Credit: Chris Carlson/AP 
R ecords show he bought the $369,000 home in 2015, and neighbours told local media he had been there around two years. 
Neighbours told local media that Paddock and his girlfriend, Marilou Delaney, 62, kept a low profile and were not well known in the community. 
Police have also searched a two-bedroom home Paddock owned in a retirement community in Reno, 500 miles from Mesquite. Related Topics

posts.title: One mass shooting every day: Seven facts on gun violence in America
posts.text:
Patrick Scott , Data Journalists 11 October 2017 • 8:25am 
S tephen Paddock's gun attack at a Las Vegas country music festival has left at least 59 people dead . 
It was the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history, once again highlighting America's extreme rate of gun violence . 
The frequency of this kind of event risks anaesthetising us to the number of people who die from shootings in one of the world's most developed nations. The numbers are staggering. 1. The Las Vegas mass shooting wasn't the only mass shooting in America on Sunday 
While the scale of the attack in Las Vegas on Sunday night is unparalleled, it wasn't the only mass shooting to occur in the US that day. 
Some 13,000 miles away in Lawrence, just outside the University of Kansas in Kansas, two men and a woman were killed and a further two people injured in a mass shooting incident. 
While none of the three victims were students at the university, all were in their early twenties, with one of the young men recently having become a father, according to the local press . 
Mass shootings in America - defined as an event where at least four people are shot - are now an every day event. 
The Las Vegas attack makes October the most deadly month for mass shootings this year - although not by as much as some may think, given the scale of the atrocity. 2. One major mass shooting every two months 
T his year's deaths follow a depressing trend, according to data gathered by the Gun Violence Archive . 
S ome 346 people are estimated to have been killed in American mass shootings this year. This compared to 432 in 2016, and 369 in 2015 - more than one person for every day of the year. 
When it comes to major mass shootings (where more than four people are killed), there have been an average of just 72 days between events during the period of 2010 to 2017 . 
This is a far more frequent rate when compared to the average gap of 162 days from 2000 to 2010, according to data compiled by Mother Jones . 
The two worst mass shooting events - this week's Las Vegas shooting and the Pulse nightclub atrocity in Orlando - have occurred in the last two years. More than a person a day have been killed in US mass shootings in recent years 3. Firearms sales go up after mass shootings 
D ata from the FBI shows us that there have been 270million firearms background checks since November 1998 - and the number is increasing as time goes by. 
Such background checks, initiated through the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS), do not represent the number of firearms sold - but they do give us an idea as to interest in buying guns across the country. 
In an alarming pattern identified by the New York Times , the fear of firearms restrictions is a significant driver of gun sales - with mass shootings and other attacks being another, although to a lesser extent. 
F or example, December 2015 saw the highest number of background checks to date - at 3.3m. This followed the San Bernardino terror attack in November, in which 14 people died and after which Obama called for tighter restrictions on the purchase of assault rifles. Firearm checks peak after attacks and potential restrictions 4. 270m guns for 320m people 
I n 2007, the Small Arms Survey estimated that there were between 250m and 290m civilian-owned firearms in the US - a rate of around 90 per 100 people. 
This was the highest rate of civilian guns for any of the 178 countries that were surveyed and was ahead of Yemen (55 guns per 100 civilians) in second place by quite some distance. 
Higher rates of gun ownership correlate strongly with occurrences of mass shootings with the US emerging at the top of tree when it came to mass shootings per head in a study by Jaclyn Schildkraut of the State University of New York. Countries with more guns have more mass shootings 5. Mass shootings are just the tip of the iceberg 
B etween 2001 and 2013, 406,496 people died as a result of gun violence in America according to the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention. 
Of this number the majority - 237,052 - were actually suicides as opposed to homicides. 
H omicides accounted for 153,144 deaths over this period while the rest comprised 8,383 accidental deaths, 4,778 deaths from police shootings and 3,200 where the cause couldn't be determined. 
In this context, mass shootings make up a comparatively small proportion of overall gun deaths in the US, accounting for around three per cent of homicides in 2017 so far according to the Gun Violence Archive. Suicides account for most US gun deaths 6. Texas is often at the frontline of mass shootings 
I n 2015, there were 45 deaths from Texan mass shootings . In 2016, the state saw 39 victims. This year, the running total is 28. 
While individual large tragedies may skew the data for particular years, Texas is consistently bad for gun violence. 
After the Las Vegas attack, Nevada has suffered the most deaths from mass shootings this year - at 59 deaths - but it is also top when we make the number proportional to a state's population. 
It being a small state, Nevada has now had 20 mass shooting deaths per one million of its people - with the next highest rates seen in Mississippi (7.4 per million) and Kansas (3.4 per million). Map: America’s mass shootings hotspots 7. Americans can't agree on gun control 
T he debate over gun rights and restrictions is not a new one in America - and it's opened up every time another mass shooting catches the public's attention. 
T he latest polling from the Pew Research Centre shows that 47 per cent of Americans support protecting gun rights - compared to 51 per cent who support gun control (6 April 2017). 
This polling has tightened over the last two decades - when 65 per cent were in favour of gun control in May 1999 - ensuring that the debate continues to rage on. 
A t the end of 2016, The Telegraph published a piece called "The face of America's gun problem" which aimed to document all 432 victims of American mass shootings in 2016. Related Topics

posts.text:
Martin Evans , Crime Correspondent 3 October 2017 • 12:22pm 
A police officer has appeared in court accused of murdering his wife, who was a detective with the same force. 
Sergeant Darren McKie, 43, is accused of killing his wife, Leanne McKie, 39, at their home in Wilmslow, Cheshire on Thursday evening last week. 
Both served with Greater Manchester Police and had three young children. 
Mr McKie, appeared at Crewe Magistrates' Court, flanked by two dock officers for a short hearing. 
Appearing unshaven and wearing a grey sweatshirt and jogging bottoms, his handcuffs were taken off for the hearing. Mrs McKie's body was discovered in Poynton Lake in Cheshire Credit: MEN Media 
M r McKie nodded to confirm his name, age and address to the court clerk during the hearing, which lasted less than a minute. 
Two elderly relatives, believed to be the defendant's parents, sat in the public gallery. 
No plea was entered and reporting restrictions were not lifted. 
Rachel Barber, prosecuting, told magistrates the charge of murder can only be dealt with at the Crown Court, which will also deal with an application for bail by the defendant. 
Gavin Wells, chair of the bench, remanded McKie into custody overnight. 
He told the defendant: "You are being sent to Chester Crown Court for the offence of murder, you are to appear there tomorrow at 10am for a bail application." 
M rs McKie was found dead in a lake in Poynton Park, Cheshire, in the early hours of last Friday morning. 
Her husband was arrested shortly afterwards and was charged with her murder on Monday evening. 
She joined the police in 2001 and worked in GMPs serious sexual offences unit. 
The force's chief constable Ian Hopkins, said Mrs McKie "worked tirelessly to provide support and seek justice for victims".

posts.title: As the Government extends 'Help to Buy', what's happened to shared ownership?
posts.text:
T heresa May's pledge to pour an extra £10bn into the Government's Help to Buy scheme is aimed at winning back young voters.
With the extra funding the Government expects to help 135,000 people onto the ladder by giving them interest-free Government loans which form deposits.
The funding injection represents a major further investment in affordable housing. But could the focus on Help to Buy be responsible for the decline of another form of housebuyer assistance - shared ownership?
With Help to Buy, the Government gives qualifying homebuyers a loan (interest-free for five years) in order to reduce the size of their required mortgage. This gives them access to lower interest rates and puts more expensive properties within their reach.
By contrast, shared ownership allows buyers to own a portion of a property while renting the remainder from a housing association. Buyers have the option to "staircase" to full ownership later (see below).
Prime Minister Theresa May has announced £10bn of extra funding for the Help to Buy equity loan scheme Credit: Phil Noble/PA M ore than 50,000 shared ownership properties have been built since the scheme was promoted in 2010, but in recent years it appears to have lost popularity.
While 11,420 units were built in 2014-15, the following two years saw a huge drop off, with 4,110 built in 2015-16 and 5,430 in 2016-17.
Meanwhile, according to the Chartered Institute for Housing, the total number of affordable homes built in Britain fell by 50 percent between 2010-11 and 2016-17, from 56,000 to 28,000.
Why have fewer houses been built? Despite the decline, the Government continues to promote shared ownership - designating last week "shared ownership week" in a bid to rejuvenate interest in the programme.
The Department for Communities and Local Government, which oversees the programme, said the decline could be explained by the five-year “delivery” cycles under which it operates.
The latest cycle runs from 2016 to 2021, and a spokesman said the number of shared ownership new-builds would pick up again in the next few years.
“This Government is determined to make housing more affordable, increase supply and help more people get onto the housing ladder,” he added. “Shared ownership plays a key part in this, helping young aspiring homebuyers to achieve their dream of home ownership.” Shared ownership transactions have climbed slightly, with just over 12,000 taking place last year.

posts.title: DJ Tim Westwood at 60: why it's time to take UK rap's elder statesman seriously
posts.text:
T im Westwood turns 60 today. It’s safe to say he’s not your average sexagenarian. Clad in puffa jacket, baggy jeans and Timberland boots, the evergreen DJ will celebrate the milestone either by pretending it isn’t happening (he’s got form for fibbing about his age) or by dropping block-rocking rap anthems well into the small hours. Quite probably both.
Hip-hop is now pop music ’s dominant form and somehow this gangly 6'4'' East Anglian saw it coming before anyone else in the country. The self-styled “Big Dawg” is a pioneer who, for the past 35 years, has been the most influential figure and foremost authority on the UK scene, if not Europe-wide. 
As John Peel was to indie, Westwood is to hip-hop E ven nearing pensionable age, he remains the voice of rap. As John Peel was to indie, Westwood is to hip-hop. It’s just a shame he’s easily dismissed as a joke figure so doesn’t get his dues.
“The man Westwood”, after all, is the public school-educated bishop’s son from the mean streets of downtown Lowestoft who turned himself into the high priest of hip-hop – while becoming the inspiration for Sacha Baron Cohen’s Ali G (although as Westwood says: “I’d rather be Ali G than Bruno.”) A middle-class, middle-aged white man who acts like he’s young, black and straight outta the ‘hood.
Big Dawg: Tim Westwood in the 1990s Credit: Television Stills B eneath the much-mocked "wigga" caricature, though, Tim “no relation to Vivienne or Lee” Westwood is your classic tale of a geek made good. A dyslexic who struggled at school, he was an early adopter of the genre that would go on to take over the world. During the late Seventies, he fell in love with electro funk and early rap, obsessively collecting vinyl, making mixtapes and hero-worshipping trailblazers like Jam Master Jay and DJ Funkmaster Flex. 
Leaving home and heading for London, he gravitated towards the music business. Starting out as a roadie and West End nightclub glass collector, Westwood persuaded his boss to give him a spin on the decks as warm-up for top-of-the-bill names like dancehall don David Rodigan. His infectious passion and nerdy knowledge soon shone through. 
After serving his DJing apprenticeship on London pirate station Kiss FM (which the ever canny Westwood co-owned), then graduating to the more respectable Capital Radio, he went national in 1994 as original host of the Radio 1 Rap Show. 
Westwood is an unusual sort of national treasure H e launched his shiny new BBC vehicle with a Hammersmith Palais gig headlined by those twin East Coast titans, Puff Daddy and Notorious BIG – the rap megastars of the time. Westwood has long been instrumental in hauling hip-hop talent across the Atlantic. He was the first to bring Ja Rule and Jay Z to London (“Westwood has held me down from day one,” says Jay-Z. “He’s family – we've grown up together”). More recently, he helped break Kanye West , Lil Wayne, Nicki Minaj and Drake on these shores. 
He was respectfully name-checked on Nineties cuts by NORE, Pharoahe Monch and Jadakiss – not to mention thanked on the sleevenotes of Public Enemy’s Fear Of A Black Planet album – because he was the only British DJ playing hardcore hip-hop on mainstream, legal radio. For any visiting US rap star, a visit to Westwood was virtually compulsory on their itinerary. As Snoop Dogg says: “You can’t come to the kingdom and not see the prince.” 
A tireless champion of the genre, his zeal is undimmed. Workaholic Westwood has devoted his life to the music he loves. He’s single, childless and lives in a one-bedroom flat. It’s all about the game, baby. He’s married to hip-hop. 
His much-mocked rambunctious presentational persona was transformed by trips to New York, where he met influential DJs Marley Marl and Mister Cee. Inspired, Westwood changed his own style to “match the energy and excitement of the music, shouting and cracking that mic like I’m in a club”.
He introduced urban sound effects: gunfire, explosions, klaxons, car horns, police sirens. He created a hanging-at-the-crib vibe in the studio, with musicians’ entourages popping Cristal corks, sipping Hennessy brandy and smoking Cohiba blunts in the background. 
T eeth-rattling “heavy hits” became punctuated by slangy shout-outs and Westwood’s impassioned, much-imitated cries of “Now drop the bomb!”, “All you other DJs, fall back!”. “Get your hustle on, baby!”, “We’re going in strong!”, “We’re built for that!” ”Take it down south!”, “Bow down and kiss the ring!” or “Understand that!” 
Westwood’s got more catchphrases than a gameshow host, a crucial factor in building his instant recognition factor and unmistakable brand. As he recently explained: “With some household-name DJs, what’s their fly s--- that people say back to them? You’d struggle to name anything. But when I’m out on the road and people say, ‘Yo, we’re going in, baby!’ or ‘Drop the bomb!’… it’s like you’re winning, fam. Winning.”
In 1999, the gangsta rap lyrics he loves became all too real when Westwood was the target of a drive-by shooting. Gunmen on a motorbike pulled up alongside his Range Rover in South London and opened fire. 
“A bullet went through the back of my seat an inch from my spine,” he recalls. “Another bullet went through my arm and missed the nerves which would have left me paralysed. The guy in the back seat had his kneecap blown off. Am I not blessed? Thank God I’m alive and everyone survived.” We should all be thankful because Westwood is an unusual sort of national treasure. 
H e might be older than their fathers – in some cases, their grandfathers – but among urban artists, his DJ peers and hip-hop heads, Westwood remains one of the most respected, best-connected taste-makers out there. The Mobo Awards crowned him Best UK Radio DJ five times. Fittingly, in 2010, the Radio Academy gave him The John Peel Award for Outstanding Contribution to Music.
In 2013, Westwood left Radio 1 and 1Xtra after an heroic 19-year stint. He returned to Capital Xtra, where he still drops bombs, keeps it mad real, rocks the joint and rips down parties for four hours every Saturday night. 
His compilation albums have sold two million copies and counting. His production, promotion and events companies, which were way ahead of their time, are thriving. His YouTube channel, where he interviews rap, drill and grime artists before they bust out exclusive freestyle rhymes, has 600,000 subscribers and one-third of a billion views. 
Westwood might have qualified for his bus pass but there’s life in the old dawg yet. Like the man says: “We’ve done some legendary s--- in our time and we’ll continue to do legendary s---.” Happy birthday, my brother. We out. Peace.

posts.title: Which shops aren't taking part in Black Friday 2017 and why?
posts.text:
I n recent years Black Friday has become a week-long event for main retailers, with emails packed with bargains whizzing into inboxes and sales rails taking over shop floors across the country.
Yet there are a small band of indomitable retailers which still hold out against the pervasive discounts event, refusing to be cajoled into offering deals.
If you are considering using Black Friday to nab a discount on a big-budget addition to your home - or for holiday-season gifts - then it's good to know which shops regularly don't take part. Here's The Telegraph's handy guide to the retailers who don't embrace the cut-price chaos.
Apple Apple surprised retailers last year by taking part in Black Friday, albeit only for a brief 24-hour window. While in previous years the tech giant rejected the sales event, in 2016 they buckled to the pressure.
However their presence was somewhat underwhelming: they offered a gift card worth up to £120 with the purchase of certain Apple products (not including their recently-released iPhone 7). Needless to say, the internet was unimpressed.
So for Apple's Black Friday sale they're offering gift cards up to $200 on selected products. That's not a sale 😑
— Thomas (@DarkHorse_TM) November 24, 2016 All Apple are offering for Black Friday are gift cards when you buy Mac, iPhone, iPad, Watch or Apple TV.

Not worth the refreshes.
— Daniel Hart (@KingDingDan) November 25, 2016 W hile Apple hasn't announced yet whether or not they will taking part in the sales weekend this year, we aren't holding our breath for discounted iPhone 8s.
Selfridges Last year Selfridges officially stayed clear of Black Friday, instead creating their own holiday: Christmas Come Early. 
As well as offering consumers the discount code 'SELFCCE', this faux-Black Friday sale also included 20 per cent off gifts and 10 per cent off beauty, fragrances, watches and wine.
Keep your eyes peeled for similarly sneaky behaviour this year; just because a shop claims to be rejecting the sales event it doesn't mean they are.
Ikea Looking for a new bed on the cheap? Prepare to be disappointed. Famous for selling furniture and homeware at low prices throughout the year, Ikea don't feel the need to take part in Black Friday events.
Insisting their focus is on making affordable furniture available to as many people as possible, they say: "Low price is the cornerstone of the IKEA vision.
"Our ambition is to offer everyday low prices all year round, which is why we don't take part in temporary discounting events.”
Black Friday countdown 2017 Homebase L ike Ikea, the DIY superstore has also turned its back on Black Friday, saying it is committed to low price 365 days a year.
However they did take part in 2015, offering 25 per cent off all Christmas decorations, meaning their participation in 2017's bargain bonanza can't be ruled out entirely.
Asda Asda, the cousin of US shopping giant Wal-Mart, was one of Black Friday’s pioneers in this country. But a series of unseemly stampedes for flat-screen TVs made it clear that Black Friday and supermarkets don’t mix well.
Last year they snubbed the sales weekend for the second year in a row, initially dropping their 2015 event with the following euphemistic explanation:
"Instead of the hustle and bustle and pressure of one or two day sales where customers typically push the boat out on high-value items, this year Asda customers say they’d prefer deals on value-for-money, high-quality products that all the family can enjoy."
Primark Given that Primark doesn't have an online store it has little need to compete against rivals battling for the best online discounts.
Primark has not taken part in any major Black Friday sale thus far because, as a spokesperson for the cut-price retailer told The Telegraph : “Primark offers great value on the high street every day of the year.”
George Weston, the chief executive of Primark, was a little less polite, asserting: "Black Friday in the UK is pointless".
Next Like Primark , value clothes retailer Next maintains low profit margins throughout the year, and thus has less to gain than rivals from discounting further. So far it doesn't appear anything will be changing this year.

posts.title: Activism drama that never detonates - B, Royal Court, review
posts.text:
G uillermo Calderon’s new drama is named after the bomb that spends a fair deal of Sam Pritchard’s enervating production sitting on the floor of a cheerless urban apartment, wrapped up in white paper and red ribbon like a birthday present. But what is the bomb intended to achieve?

A ravishing, earthy set, if not quite home turf - Desire Under the Elms, Sheffield Crucible, review The two young jumpy female activists and their much older accomplice, Jose, who are holed up in the flat, are divided. They can’t even decide what to call it – at times opting for the codeword “cheese”, at others “cow”. The girls, members of an anti capitalist, non violent cell, want to set off the bomb at 3am outside a bank when no one will be around. But Jose, an experienced political activist, has packed it full of nails and is convinced that the only way to make both the morning and the evening news – in other words, to get heard – is to start a war.
Danusia Samal, Aimee-Ffion Edwards and Paul Kaye Credit: Alastair Muir I suspect that this play resonates far more powerfully in Calderon’s native Chile than it is likely to do here. Over the past decade, Chile has experienced a wave of non-lethal bomb attacks, with no single group taking responsibility.
That Calderon has written a play about an undetonated bomb that contains barely an ounce of tension tells its own story. Youth protest today, the play argues, is so denuded of coherent ideology and purpose that it has been rendered virtually impotent. Alejandra and Marcela – both a bit hapless, using jumpers as makeshift balaclavas, and incapable even of spinning a convincing story to their neighbour to cover what they are cooking up in the flat – want to protest against “everything”. But Jose is a veteran of direct action. Where is the peasant revolution, he wonders. Where is the hunger for real change?
Danusia Samal in Guillermo Calderon's play Credit: Alastair Muir C alderon’s stop-start dialogue – purposefully anaemic a lot of the time – has shades of Pinter at his most farcical. Pritchard’s production revels in these bland, jerking rhythms in ways that compound Calderon’s satirical swipes at the self-serving arguments of terrorism, but neither play nor production achieve enough momentum to keep you really hooked.
King Lear review: Ian McKellen reigns supreme in this triumphant production Implicit in Calderon’s play is a critique of a political system in Chile that offers its youth so little that Alejandra is ambivalent about the prospect of prison – after all, at least she’d get to see some of her friends. Yet the tone is so persistently ironic and detached that his arguments never fully connect. Pritchard’s production has flashes of nicely judged absurdity and there is a pitch perfect performance from Sarah Niles as the disconcertingly friendly neighbour, Carmen. But rather than worry about a ticking bomb, I found myself mainly checking my watch.
Until Oct 21. Tickets: 020 7565 5000; royalcourttheatre.com

posts.title: Nobel Prize for Physics awarded to team who found gravitational waves - ripples in the fabric of spacetime
posts.text:
T he team who discovered gravitational waves - ripples in space and time - have been awarded the Nobel Prize of Physics.
The waves were predicted by Einstein in his General Theory of relativity, but were not recorded for more than 100 years.
They were finally spotted in 2016 by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Ligo) in a discovery was hailed as "the biggest scientific breakthrough" of the century by scientists.
Today the Nobel Prize was awarded to Rainer Weiss of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Barry Barish and Kip Thorne of the California Institute of Technology, all members of the Ligo team.
"Their discovery shook the world," said Goran Hansson, the head of the Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences , who announced the prize today.
BREAKING NEWS The 2017 #NobelPrize in Physics is awarded to Rainer Weiss, Barry C. Barish and Kip S. Thorne @LIGO . pic.twitter.com/za1GNsAfnE
— The Nobel Prize (@NobelPrize) October 3, 2017 B ut British physicist Ronald Drever, who was a key member of the team, missed out on science's most coveted prize, after losing his battle with dementia earlier this year.
Professor James Hough, of the University of Glasgow’s School of Physics and Astronomy, added: “Back in the 1970s, working with Ron Drever we built one of the world’s first gravitational wave detectors, instrumented with piezoelectric transducers, before moving on to designing increasingly sophisticated technology.
“I’m proud to have played a leading role in the conception and expansion of gravitational research Glasgow, and that the efforts of Glasgow researchers over the decades paid off both with the development of LIGO’s mirror-suspension technology, and now exciting roles in delivering the astrophysical results from the brand new field.”
In 1915 Einstein announced his General Theory of Relativity which suggested that huge bodies in space, like planets or black holes, have so much mass that they actually bend space and time.
It can be thought of as a giant rubber sheet with a bowling ball in the centre. Just as the ball warps the sheet, so a planet bends the fabric of space-time creating the force that we feel as gravity. Any object that comes near to the body falls towards it because of the effect.
Einstein predicted that if two massive bodies came together it would create such a huge ripple in space time that it should be detectable on Earth.
Moment scientists reveal major gravitational wave finding 00:40 I n Feburary last year, the Ligo announced they had detected such a ripple, believed to be caused by two black holes colliding. The experiment has since been confirmed and replicated by other observatories.
Professor Mark Hannam, from Cardiff University’s School of Physics and Astronomy, said: “LIGO has already given us a string of discoveries - the first direct detection of gravitational waves, the first observation of a binary black hole system, the first observation of black holes several tens of times more massive than the sun, and arguably the first direct observation of a black hole. But the truly incredible achievement was to make the LIGO detectors.
"We already knew gravitational waves existed. We already knew black holes existed. What Weiss, Thorne and Barish did was to build the first machine sensitive enough to be able to directly measure gravitational waves.
"It took them over forty years, and the result was the most sensitive measuring device ever made. It is an incredible new tool that has only begun to transform our understanding of the universe.
"It’s very sad that one of the UK’s gravitational-wave pioneers, Ron Drever, didn’t live to see this fantastic recognition of these ground-breaking discoveries.
"However, he was alive to witness the first ever detection of gravitational waves in 2015, and I understand he was extremely thrilled.”
German-born Weiss was awarded half of the 9-million-kronor ($1.1 million) prize amount and Thorne and Barish will split the other half.
Prof Lord Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal & Fellow of Trinity College, University of Cambridge, said: “The Nobel committee has apportioned credit appropriately among three leaders of the LIGO project - outstanding individuals whose contributions were distinctive and complementary.
"Weiss deserves prime credit for devising (along with the late Ron Drever) the amazingly precise laser techniques. Moreover he was 'hands on' and saw the project through to its success."

posts.author: Richard Holt
posts.title: A glamorous golden oldie: a rare 1953 Oldsmobile Ninety Eight Fiesta gets set for auction
posts.text:
I n the 21st Century, the car industry is trying to do two very different things. On the one hand it is producing an increasing number of crazily powerful cars that bring high-speed driving within the reach of ever more people. On the other hand, it is trying to prepare itself for the day, not long from now, when driving on the road will not be entrusted to anything so fallible and clumsy as a human being.
The impressively imposing car, which was a star of the 50's Motorama fair Credit: Erik Fuller S oon car companies must decide how much resource to put into each of these diverging priorities. Driving just for the fun of it will become a niche activity, something that a small number of die-hard motorists do on private land, far from lampposts and pedestrians. Everyone else will just want comfortable, safe, autonomous vehicles that do as they are told.
The retro interior Credit: Erik Fuller W e all know this is inevitable, the only uncertainty is how long it will all take. The car industry is no longer some great adventure into the unknown, because we know where it is heading. In mid-20th century USA, however, there was new money, new technology, and endless confidence. The car industry was like Silicon Valley is today, selling products that offer a view into a previously unimaginable future, allowing the consumer to see far beyond the limits of his home town.
The car was full of the latest technology Credit: Erik Fuller G eneral Motors was then the largest company in the world and throughout the 1950s it led the charge with a series of glitzy roadshows called Motorama, where it would show off all the latest Cadillacs, Buicks and Oldsmobiles, along with fancy prototypes and concept cars. In keeping with the industry’s position as a tech leader, GM did not limit itself to cars, but had fashion shows produced by the company’s own design team, and screened slick movies showing fully automated kitchens of the future.
The Oldsmobile pictured here is a rarity – a show car created for the 1953 Motorama that was actually made available to the public, albeit in limited numbers. The Ninety-Eight Fiesta had all the latest innovations beneath its two-tone paint job, including a wraparound windscreen, spinning wheel covers, as well as power steering, power brakes and power windows – it even had a power seat, in 1953.
Its striking two-tone paint job Credit: Erik Fuller A new car launch in the car in the 1950s could create the same buzz as a new iPhone being unveiled today. But watching a striking new car like this being paraded along a catwalk cannot be compared to the sight of a middle-aged pluto-nerd holding up a phone that looks suspiciously like the one he showed us last time. This car is a reminder not just of a golden age of motoring, but of a golden age full-stop. This was a time when you could get into a car and drive into the future, rather than watch it on a little screen.
The classic car is set for auction through RM Sotheby's Credit: Erik Fuller T he 1953 Oldsmobile Ninety Eight Fiesta is Lot 153 in the RM Sotheby’s Hershey sale in Pennsylvania, USA, on Thursday October 5th. Estimate $150,000 - $175,000 (£110,000 - £130,000)

posts.author: Gordon Rayner
posts.title: Philip Hammond rebukes Boris Johnson as he says no one is 'unsackable'
posts.text:
P hilip Hammond has delivered a clear rebuke to Boris Johnson for “downplaying” the complexities of Brexit as he continued his feud with the Foreign Secretary.
The Chancellor said “focus” and “unity” would be needed if Britain was to come out of the Brexit negotiations with a good deal.
And he warned that the Foreign Secretary that no minister was “unsackable”.
Meanwhile, Sir Michael Fallon , the Defence Secretary, espoused the virtues of “discipline and loyalty” in a sideways reference to Mr Johnson on a day when he faced mounting criticism from his Cabinet colleagues.
Mr Hammond, speaking a day before Mr Johnson makes his own conference speech, said Britain will remain “closely linked with the EU” following Brexit, and stressed the need for a “careful and cautious” negotiation.
Mr Hammond addressed the conference on Monday Credit: Geoff Pugh M r Johnson used articles in The Daily Telegraph and The Sun last month to set out his Brexit “red lines” and to demand that his Cabinet colleagues started to show more optimism about Brexit.
Mr Johnson believes Britain should be prepared to leave the EU without a deal, and has suggested too many of his colleagues are downplaying the benefits of leaving the EU.
Mr Hammond took the opposite approach in his speech, saying: “If we get this right – Britain will have a bright future beyond Brexit. But to get to it, we must be clear-eyed about the challenges along our way.
“We must not downplay the difficulties nor underestimate the complexities. This will be one of the most challenging tasks ever undertaken by a peacetime government but with focus and determination and unity, we will succeed.”
Mr Johnson’s conference speech on Tuesday will be arguably the most anticipated of the conference in ­Manchester.
Philip Hammond and his wife Susan Williams-Walker at the Conservative party conference Credit: Geoff Pugh for the Telegraph T he reception it gets could make or break his ambitions of one day leading his party, and if he is seen as being disloyal it could also increase calls from some of his Cabinet colleagues for Theresa May to sack him.
Mr Hammond did not name Mr Johnson in his speech, but in another barb clearly aimed at him, he said the Government must “pick our way carefully and cautiously across the difficult terrain of EU negotiation, to ensure we arrive in good order on the fertile plains at the other side”, adding that “focus, determination and unity” would be needed to succeed.
In a series of media interviews earlier in the day, Mr Hammond had said that Mr Johnson was “sackable”, after the Prime Minister refused to answer a question on Sunday about whether the Foreign Secretary was sackable.
He also suggested Mr Johnson’s disloyalty was making it harder for David Davis, the Brexit Secretary, to negotiate in ­Brussels.
He said: “The more we can show unity, the stronger our negotiating position with the European Union would be. His hand would be stronger when it is clear that he has a united Cabinet behind him.”
Boris Johnson arrives at party conference 00:25 A sked about Mr Johnson’s claim that the Brexit transition period should be “two years and not a second more”, he shrugged: “I would describe that as a rhetorical flourish.”
Mr Hammond suggested that Mrs May had given Britain “flexibility” over the length of the Brexit transition period by saying it would last “around” two years. Damian Green, the First Secretary of State, said the transition period could last “a few months either side” of two years. The Daily Telegraph understands that several Cabinet ministers believe a period of two and a half years would be acceptable.
Sir Michael Fallon was also scathing when asked about Mr Johnson’s chances of becoming the next Tory leader.
Speaking on Chopper’s Brexit Podcast, Sir Michael said his advice to his squabbling colleagues was to “have a look at the military. People admire our military the world over … Why? Because of … those virtues of discipline and loyalty”.
He said a poll that showed 21 per cent of Tory members wanted Mr Johnson as the next leader “doesn’t seem extremely high”.
Boris Johnson went for a jog on the morning of Mr Hammond's speech Credit: Geoff Pugh S peaking on the same programme, the former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith said Mrs May needed to show by the end of the conference that she could “lead a united party, or we will not succeed”.
Nicky Morgan, the former education secretary, said Mr Johnson “had to go” unless he could demonstrate his loyalty within days.
Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned if Conservative cabinet ministers did not "pull in behind" Mrs May they would be "risking Brexit."
Asked by the Guardian if he feared Mr Johnson was "looking for the top job," Mr Hunt said: "All I would say to anyone who might be eyeing a different job is that Jeremy Corbyn is also eyeing a different job.
"And if they don’t swing behind Theresa, who I think is doing a fantastic job in very difficult circumstances, they will just open the door to Jeremy Corbyn and probably the most dangerous leftwing government this country has ever seen."
Speaking at a Conservative conference fringe event, Mr Green refused to rule out paying for single market access after the Brexit transition period – which would cross one of Mr Johnson’s red lines.
He said: “I’m not ruling anything in or out that will be in the detail of the negotiation because David Davis has got a difficult job and he is eminently suited to doing it.
“I’m not going to do anything that makes his job more difficult.”
Steve Baker, a Brexit minister, issued a further jibe at Mr Johnson at a conference fringe event, insisting he would not be wading into the “unfortunately public debate” about the nature of a transitional deal.

posts.text:
Fill 1 Man up? Many men feel they have to suffer in silence 
"Just when you think you've heard everything! Bloody man-opause what a croc of s***. Another excuse for men to behave badly." 
T his was just one of many livid tweets hurled at me during a recent breakfast TV appearance. As a writer specialising in men's issues, I'd been invited onto the sofa to talk about the andropause (male menopause), alongside one of the most respected hormone specialists in the country. Despite Marion Gluck's assertion that men of a certain age did indeed suffer from menopausal type symptoms, many female viewers remained unconvinced. 
"Anything we can do men can do it more dramatically" screeched one angry viewer; "menopause - is it just like man-flu?" sneered another. Even autocorrect changes it to menopause so it clearly doesn't exist - manopause #thismorning — Julie (@mrst43) August 8, 2017 
B ut why the withering attacks? A blood test carried out by Marion had revealed that my hormone levels were down, resulting in increased levels of anxiety and depression. She prescribed a course of supplements and within a few weeks I had noticed a marked improvement in my mental and physical wellbeing. Hardly controversial. Indeed one of the reasons I agreed to appear on the show was to encourage men to talk more openly about their health concerns. 
The host of the show, Eamonn Holmes, spoke out against the naysayers . "I could not sit here and criticise any female condition in that way," he argued live on TV "so it absolutely amazes me that there’s not some sort of empathy or realisation that if it happens to one species of human being, the same has to happen to the other one." 
My social media drubbing was a salient reminder of why so many men feel they have to suffer in silence. The outdated notion that men should remain stiff-upper-lipped at all times continues, with many women seeing ill health as a sign of weakness. A close friend revealed recently that he no longer turns to his wife when illness strikes: "there's no point, she just rolls her eyes and tells me to man-up". Another friend told me that his girlfriend had abandoned him when he contracted acute appendicitis: "I spent several days doubled up in excruciating agony but she barely acknowledged my existence". James Innes-Smith appeared on This Morning to talk about the manopause 
I know the feeling. While holidaying in Thailand a few years back I suffered a particularly virulent bout of food poisoning. My girlfriend and I were staying in one of those bug-infested beach huts with a hole in the floor for a loo and a rusty outside tap. Instead of standing by her man through fevered babblings and frequent visits to the unsanitary hole, the light-of-my-life left me to stew in my own filth while she took in the delights of Koh Phi Phi. Apparently I'd been "over-dramatic", but how else are you supposed to projectile vomit? 
At this time of year many of us will have the "over-dramatic" label thrown at us. Understand that when a woman accuses you of having man-flu what she's really saying is "you have a mild case of the sniffles, get over it and don’t expect any brow-mopping from me." 
Apparently men will never know the true meaning of pain until we learn to give birth. But according to research men are more susceptible to certain kinds of pain. For two years Dr. Andreas Sander-Kiesling from the department of anaesthesiology and intensive care at the Medical University of Graz in Austria assessed the records of over 10,000 patients undergoing a variety of surgeries. They were asked to rate their pain levels within 24 hours of procedures. Men were 27pc more likely to report feeling more pain after major invasive operations such as heart surgery, while women showed higher pain readings after more routine operations such as biopsies. 
So it turns out we're not all a bunch of needy weaklings. Okay, we may occasionally exaggerate our symptoms for dramatic effect, adding a phlegmy hawk here, a pitiful moan there – but who doesn’t relish being cosseted by a concerned lover every now and then? 
Ladies, next time your man is feeling under the weather, don’t just shake your head in disbelief. He may be feeling under loved or under appreciated; he may just be looking for a little reassurance and a kind word; or, God forbid, he might even be going through something major like the manopause. Give him the benefit of the doubt, mop his brow, be the bearer of comforting Lemsip, tell him he'll feel better in the morning. And if his symptoms persist, take him kicking and screaming down to the nearest GP surgery. 
After all, what goes around comes around.

D rinks writers Joel Harrison and Neil Ridley have visited a LOT of bars. The best speakeasy: The Drifter, Chicago 
It’s not been long since this bar was discovered, in the literal sense, when an old man punched a hole in the basement wall of The Green Door Tavern with his stick. It turns out that behind the door was a Prohibition-era burlesque bar completely intact, bottles still behind the bar; the hand-painted burlesque posters still hanging; the stage in place; a few dirty glasses on the bar. It sounds as corny as can be, but it’s not.
