posts.author: Rosa Silverman
posts.title: The tyranny of the smartphone: 6 notifications that drive us bananas
posts.text:
Rosa Silverman 3 October 2017 • 12:37pm 
I magine if every time you sat down to do anything, a friend or family member popped round to impart some little snippet of information, a greeting or morsel of gossip, and then popped back out again, only to return shortly afterwards with something else. It would seem nice at first, because we all like feeling connected to others. 
But if it kept happening, throughout the day, and the interruptions grew incessant, it would soon drive you bananas. By the end of the day, you’d be just about ready to punch the next person who interrupted you. 
And yet almost any smartphone user will gladly suffer this level of disruption in their every waking hour, courtesy of the endless notifications we receive from our devices. 
Anyone who’s been a member of a busy WhatsApp group or Facebook Messenger conversation will be familiar with this. We frequently wake up to a string of new messages, scrolling through them, zombie-like, before we even leave our beds. We compulsively check them last thing at night. And in the intervening hours? A constant stream of notifications alerts us to every muscle twitch or half-thought experienced by our contacts. 
Now, surprise surprise, we learn this is not making us happy. One third of notifications that pop up cause a downturn in our mood, researchers have found . Rather than gladdening our hearts, they frequently leave us feeling hostile, upset, nervous, afraid or ashamed. Catching up with a WhatsApp conversation you're behind on can take up aeons of your time Credit: DADO RUVIC/REUTERS 
“None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free,” wrote Goethe in 1809. How apt this seems now, in an age when we all are so willingly yoked to our smartphones, encaged in prisons of our own making. 
S o how do our phones imprison and annoy us? Let us count the ways. 1. The hyperactive WhatsApp group 
Don’t your friends have jobs? How is it possible that you can turn away for 10 minutes and then return to find 56 new messages in the thread? This presents you with a dilemma: do you write off the missed ones and start again from the bottom, or scroll through every last message in case you’ve missed something crucial? Sometimes the information you need - the name of the restaurant you’re meeting at, for instance - will be hidden halfway up the chain. Ignoring the thread feels too risky. Reading it takes up aeons of your time. First world problem? Maybe, but it’s a bloody difficult one. What's everyone going to wear? This question alone can spark a subsidiary thread of 40 messages pinging into your consciousness 2. The event-planning thread 
I t might be a hen or stag do , or someone’s 40th birthday. It might be a weekend away with friends, or even just a meal. Whatever it is, you can’t remember how you ever used to organise such things without the requisite 800 planning messages. 
Even subsidiary questions - who is bringing parmesan for the Friday night arrival supper? Who is arriving at which station and when? How is everyone planning to interpret the “creative black tie ” dress code? - can branch off into discussions of 40 messages or more. 
I’ve been on hen dos where the time I’ve spent reading the planning messages beforehand has actually exceeded the time I’ve spent there. This surely can’t be right. 3. The ‘interloper’ pictures 
Why have you got six photos of a baby you can’t even identify in your own smartphone picture collection? That would be because they’ve been sent to you at some point and your phone has taken it upon itself to absorb these interloper images into your own picture library. 
If you didn’t have to spend so much time deleting these, you might actually find the time to go and visit this baby, whoever it belongs to. What a beautiful baby. But whose is it, and why is it in your phone? Credit: Stockbroker / Alamy Stock Photo 4. The work email 
Y our work email is on your smartphone and your boss knows this, so no excuse not to reply when you’re in bed/on holiday/on the loo. The longer you put it off, the more messages you’ll have to wade through when you do bite the bullet and check your inbox. The worst thing you can do is glance at them and resolve to respond later as you are 99 per cent sure to forget. 5. The banter 
This can take place across a range of platforms - WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, email - and requires a quick-fire response. No-one wants to be that person who comes to a thread full of jokes some five hours after the last message was sent, and in vain tries to join in with a now irrelevant piece of wit. Everyone’s moved on. Don’t be that person. (NB I am usually that person.) If your email inbox was in paper form, it would look like this Credit: RichLegg/ Getty Images Contributor 6. The time-consuming video 
P ing! Someone has sent you a video, which is lovely, except that now you have to find the time to watch it as they will be expecting feedback. 
It may even be a video of your own children, sent by whoever is looking after them that day , but the fact remains you’re now going to have to spend precious minutes finding headphones so you can watch several more minutes of delightfulness, then replying with something delighted-sounding. 
It’s exhausting and, frankly, who has the time? Related Topics

posts.title: Forza Motorsport 7 review | An exceptional and exhilarating racer
posts.text:
Forza Motorsport 7 review | An exceptional and exhilarating racer 4 Tom Hoggins 3 October 2017 • 12:32pm 
L ike the screeching, wavering back tyres after a scuffed exit from a hairpin, it is fair to say that Forza Motorsport has had a slight wobble over the past few entries. Nothing too damaging to the driving sim’s reputation, but perhaps not quite the example of precise perfection it has prided itself on. Motorsport 5 was a stripped down disappointment, while 6 corrected that mistake with terrific driving and plenty of stuff but no defined direction. To an extent, the track-based stalwart has seen its brasher, open-world offspring, Forza Horizon , whizz past it in terms of critical acclaim. 
Developers Turn 10 told The Telegraph that each Forza game informs the other. And for the first time for the parent game, this feels very much the truth. Forza Motorsport 7 is a brilliant, bold and more care-free racer, throwing variety and challenge at you as fast as its cars tear around the track. That isn’t to say that Turn 10 has diluted its superb but accessible simulation, far from it, but in terms of style, 7 is the series at its best. Many more tracks have rain and night options, which changes the dynamic of a race considerably. 
B ut first: that driving. Forza 7 is an extraordinary showcase of audio, visual and tactile feedback, even before we have played the enhanced Xbox One X version. The cars are ferociously loud, with guttural engines roaring as you tear down straights, exhausts crackling and popping on deceleration, the scream of tyres on tarmac. 
It assaults the ears and the eyes. As you escape the baking sun of Dubai and enter a tunnel the echo of engines thunders against the concrete, when passing the statues on Prague’s Charles Bridge each one is accompanied by the whoosh of air, speed through a puddle on a sodden corner of Silverstone and there is an almighty whumph as the car jerks and water spatters the camera. 
Most importantly, you can feel it in the fingers. While real aficionados will be cracking out their steering wheel, I’m not sure there is a game better suited to the Xbox One’s mechanical controller. The measured rumble in the triggers reacts to each dip and bump in the tarmac as you feather the accelerator through a turn. Each vehicle, whether its threading a Porsche Spyder through the pack or wrenching a hulking truck around the track, feels just as you may have imagined it. 
And that’s the thing with Forza: everything is cranked up to 11. It’s as if Turn 10 has taken the dream of driving these vehicles and reproduced that, rather than complete authenticity. Realistic enough, certainly, particularly as you reduce the assists and the roster becomes even wilder to handle. It is exhilarating stuff, though racers wanting 100% accuracy might have their heads turned by more slavish simulations like Assetto Corsa and iRacing or the depth of Project Cars 2. Forza is an accessible sim for a mainstream audience, meaning things like the AI being both aggressive but easily outmuscled. Shunting and trading paint as you vie for position in the pack is certainly not encouraged, but doesn’t bring the penalty that it should. Forza Motorsport is in no way an arcade racer, but you are given choice and leeway in how you want to drive. Forza | Series timeline 
T hat is also what marks the single-player career in Forza Motorsport 7 as a real improvement for the series. The old style of driving sims have you starting slow and building up a cash and car collection, keeping many of its treats under lock and key. This game’s Forza Driver's Cup has the sense to not make things too restrictive, immediately putting you behind the wheel of a supercar. Within the first few races, you will have had the option of truck racing, Gymkhana and even whipping a limousine around the Top Gear track sideswiping bowling pins. 
You still have to work towards certain goals of course, and there is still a strong thread of building a vast garage filled with everything from tricked out Vauxhall Astras to classic muscle cars to squealing track toys. Your progression through each of the career’s six Championship ranks is gated by your ‘collection’ level, which progresses each time you add a vehicle to your garage. Collecting is an intoxicating part of any racing game, but Forza 7 makes sure to pepper your progress with one-off challenges. Like whipping around Brands Hatch in a Brabham BT-24 while surrounded by other 60s open-wheeled racers. Or using the latest Porsche 911 GT2 RS to try and overtake a conga line of previous models. 
T here’s an argument that the career is too unstructured, a great mess of activities to sift through. But it is enormously good fun, injected with momentum and choice that means it doesn’t wear its tyres down too quickly. Compared with the occasional grind of previous games, giving you more freedom to just get behind the wheel is a marked upgrade. And if you do want to break away from the Drivers Cup, ‘Rival’ challenges pit you against ghosts of other players, dropping you in a specific car on a specific track and asking you to beat their lap time in a rolling challenge. 
Where Forza 7 is less successful is in the introduction of ‘mods’, cards unlocked via loot crates. Which are in turn bought with in-game credits. These limited-use cards allow you to earn more XP for each race by adding a modifier or target. Execute a certain number of good passes or perfect corners, say, or ensure you finish 1st in a particular race. It’s all fine, and can add a little extra challenge on each race, but feels including more because loot crates are very much en vogue than because it fits Forza. It also means that players that drive with no assists (or gradually switch them off as they improve) do not get extra reward for their skills. That this has been reduced to a slightly confusing, slightly random card game seems a bit unnecessary. Still, Forza is rarely one to turn down the chance to toy with gaming fads. Even Destiny’s wandering merchant Xur is an inspiration here, with a specialist dealer that sells special cars at limited times. 
Frippery aside, Forza Motorsport 7 is an exceptional, exhilarating and absurdly polished racing game. It may lack the depth of some of its more serious competition, but it finally feels comfortable in its framework as a more accessible and energetic simulation.

What is it? T his is the draw for the 2018 World Cup - the flagship international football event, which is due to be held from June 14 to July 15 next year in Russia.
When and where is it? The 2018 World Cup draw will take place in Russia's capital city of Moscow on December 1. The ceremony will take place in the State Kremlin Palace, which is frequently used as a concert hall.
According to a Fifa spokesman: " This prestigious entertainment venue with a capacity of 6,000 spectators has hosted many international and locally renowned artists in the past, as well as traditional ballets and operas." 
The 2018 draw will take place in Moscow Credit: getty images How does the draw work? A total of 32 teams will feature at the 2018 World Cup, 31 of them coming through a qualifying campaign and one (Russia) making it as host nation.
Those 32 teams will be split into four pots based on their Fifa world rankings. Pot 1 will contain Russia and the highest-ranked seven teams. Pot 2 will feature the next best eight teams, and so on for Pots 3 and 4.
The draw will divide the 32 teams into eight groups of four. Each group will play three matches, before the top two countries advance to the second round.
All eyes will be on the Russian capital Credit: afp Which teams will feature in the draw? T he confirmed 32-team line-up will not be known until late November, once all qualification is complete. Africa will be the last region to conclude its qualifying process, with all inter-confederation play-offs due to finish by November 14.
Argentina are struggling in South American qualifying Credit: AFP A s of October 5, the teams who have already booked their place for Russia 2018 are:
R ussia, Brazil, Iran, Japan, Mexico, Belgium, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Germany and England.

posts.title: Savers who transfer pensions are ill-advised in 53pc of cases, says watchdog
posts.text:
Sam Brodbeck 3 October 2017 • 12:33pm 
S avers trying to swap their "final salary" pensions for cash face a crackdown from the City watchdog following a damning report into the quality of financial advice they are receiving. 
Growing numbers of people are swapping final salary pensions for "defined contribution" plans. 
This involves giving up guaranteed, inflation-proofed income for life, in return for often highly attractive cash offers and greater flexibility over how pensions can be spent. It is thought about 80,000 transfers have taken place this year alone. 
Financial advice is required by law when savers transfer final salary benefits worth £30,000 or more, but an investigation by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has found that in many cases the advice is poor. 
Over two years it has reviewed 88 cases where an adviser recommended the saver transfer out of a pension. It agreed this was the right thing to do in only 47pc of the examined cases. 
In the majority of cases the watchdog either said a transfer was "unsuitable", or it was unclear whether it was the right thing to do. 
The analysis also raised suspicions that advisers who encouraged savers to transfer out of their pensions were doing so in order to then sell them investments. The review concluded, for instance, that only a third (35pc) of the investments recommended by the adviser after a transfer were suitable. 
In recent months the FCA has intensified its examination of pension transfers. 
Four advice firms have stopped advising on transfers after the watchdog intervened, while a further 16 companies have agreed to stop conducting transfers as a result of its work on preventing scams, the FCA said. 
That has led to a severe lack of supply of advisers leaving many people, including dozens of Telegraph Money readers, unable to find an adviser to help them move their pension. The regulator has confirmed that it only requires savers to take advice before transferring: it does not matter what the advice is. 
The latest findings will spark fears the watchdog, which is due to published updated rules this year, will make it harder for savers to move their money even where there is a clear advantage to doing so. 
Advisers and regulators are anxious to ensure the pension mis-selling scandal of the Eighties and Nineties is not repeated. 
However, a crackdown or even ban on transfers would bar millions of people from the "pension freedom" reforms that have revolutionised the savings market over the past two years. 
Nathan Long, of pension firm Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "The starting point for anyone with a final salary pension should be to assume it is best left as it is. 
"Transferring usually means giving up a promised income in return for the uncertainties of investing in the stock market. 
"But it could work out in savers' advantage in certain circumstances for example if they are in poor health, are single or have concerns about the employer that provides the pension."

posts.title: Gunman Stephen Paddock was helped by some of the most relaxed gun laws in the US
posts.text:
David Millward , US Correspondent 3 October 2017 • 2:55pm 
S tephen Paddock, the Las Vegas gunman, was helped by Nevada having some of the most relaxed gun laws in the US with the governor, Brian Sandoval, being given an "A" rating by the National Rifle Association. 
In 2014 the NRA gave Mr Sandoval a glowing endorsement as he ran for re-election. 
“As Governor, Brian Sandoval has consistently showed his commitment to the Second Amendment by signing important pro-gun reform legislation, including measures to improve Nevada’s concealed carry law," said Chris Cox, chairman of the NRA's political victory fund. 
Mr Sandoval earned the NRA's praise for vetoing a bill which would have tightened background checks on all gun sales in the state. 
He said the bill did “little to prevent criminals from unlawfully obtaining firearms.” Concert-goers take cover during Las Vegas shooting 00:34 
“Senate Bill 221, while laudable in its efforts to strengthen reporting requirements concerning mentally ill persons, imposes unreasonable burdens and harsh penalties upon law-abiding Nevadans, while doing little to prevent criminals from unlawfully obtaining firearms,” Sandoval wrote in his veto statement." 
H is veto came at a time when there were growing calls for gun laws to be tightened following the Sandy Hook massacre in December 2012 which claimed the lives of 20 children and six staff members at an elementary school in Connecticut. 
Mr Sandoval, who justified his stance as protecting Americans' second amendment right to bear arms, was condemned by critics, including Michael Bloomberg, then the New York mayor. 
“Rather than sign sensible legislation that keeps guns out of the hands of convicted felons and the mentally ill, Governor Sandoval has decided to preserve the loopholes that they use to buy guns," he said. 
Nevada also imposes no restrictions on the capacity of magazines which firearms enthusiasts are able to clip onto their guns. In brief | Worst US mass shootings 
L arge capacity magazines, capable of holding up to 100 rounds of ammunition, make it possible for a shooter to kill and maim a large number of people very quickly. 
Adam Lanza, the gunman at Sandy Hook, had fitted 30-round magazines to his weapon, making it possible for him to fire 154 rounds in under five minutes. 
In common with all but eight states, Nevada imposes no restrictions on magazine - or clip - size. 
During the 2016 presidential election, Hillary Clinton called for assault rifles, currently only banned in seven states, to be outlawed. Brian Sandoval Credit: Sam Wasson/Getty 
P addock's lethal potential was increased by using devices known as "bump-stocks" , which effectively turned his semi-automatic rifle into a machine gun - weapons which have been illegal since 1986. 
"This replacement shoulder stock turns a semi-automatic rifle into a weapon that can fire at a rate of 400 to 800 rounds per minute," warned Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat senator from California. 
Several of the weapons recovered from Paddock's hotel room and home had been modified. Related Topics

posts.text:
Chris Williams 3 October 2017 • 2:53pm 
T he Chancellor has called on big business to help defend the market economy from the “existential challenge” posed by Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party. 
Philip Hammond demanded action from business leaders at a private dinner at the Conservative Party Conference that the Government. 
Attendees told The Telegraph that Mr Hammond was clear that the Government views the rising popularity of Mr Corbyn’s left-wing policies of large scale renationalisation and intervention as a threat to which business leaders must react. Highlights | Conservative Party Conference 2017 
H e said would not ask big businesses to pledge public support to the Conservative Party, but did demand that they speak out in favour of free markets. 
Mr Hammond earlier said: “This challenge, this existential challenge to our economic model, has to be responded to by all those who believe in the market and all those who live by the market. 
“It cannot be left to one political party to make the case for the market economy. We do not expect big business, PLC business, to engage in party political debate. We do not expect PLCs to support political parties. 
“But I do expect them to support the case for the market and I do not expect business to pull its punches in making the case for the market economy that has doubled our living standards in the last 35 years.” Philip Hammond delivers his conference speech 
C arolyn Fairbairn, the director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, to which Mr Hammond addressed his appeal for help, said the big business lobby would work with all parties to “ensure the best environment to support jobs and investment”. 
But she added: “We are absolutely clear that an enterprise-led economy underpinned by responsible businesses – working in partnership with the Government – is the single most effective way of raising living standards in communities across the country.” 
The Chancellor spoke after his speech to the conference on Monday came under attack from business groups frustrated by an apparent lack of progress on the shape of Brexit . 
Mr Hammond heard appeals from business leaders to finalise a transition deal with the EU by the end of the year to avoid companies taking decisions to move some operations abroad. 
He warned that it would be challenging to meet that deadline, however, as it would mean “driving a coach and horses through the EU’s conception of how this process will work”. Brussels has insisted there can be no transition deal until the divorce bill is finalised.

posts.text:
Telegraph Reporters 3 October 2017 • 2:49pm 
P eter and Tracey Wilkinson did all they could to help homeless Aaron Barley - providing him with food, shelter and even a job in the year before he launched a deadly knife attack on their family . 
After the 24-year-old pleaded guilty to murdering Mrs Wilkinson and her 13-year-old son Pierce at their Stourbridge home, Mr Wilkinson has told how they offered Barley sanctuary when his wife found him shivering and begging outside her local Tesco. 
Explaining how his wife met Barley outside the supermarket in March last year, Mr Wilkinson said her efforts to help him were typical of her kind nature, which also saw her volunteer to help the elderly. 
Mr Wilkinson, 47, was also attacked along with his daughter Lydia. He managed to phone the emergency services after being stabbed six times and spent 11 days in hospital recovering from his wounds. In his own words, Peter Wilkinson describes his family's ordeal 
“My wife was a very compassionate woman. She wouldn’t see harm come to anybody, she liked to help people. 
“She did a certain amount of voluntary work helping old people. She was very chatty and made people feel at ease." On how his wife first encountered her killer 
"She was shopping one day at Tesco in Stourbridge and she came out and Aaron was keeping warm in a cardboard box and she was taken aback by this, and decided off-the-cuff that she wanted to help him. 
“So she took him in her car to Dudley Council to get help and from that point he lived in a hostel for a few days, organised by my wife. That was in March 2016. 
“Things developed from there. Even though he was in a hostel, he had no money and food, so Tracey would organise breakfast and dinner for him every day, be it at our house or somewhere else. Tracey Wilkinson was described by her husband as 'stylish... elegant... very compassionate' Credit: Caters 
“I remember after that talking to him one of the evenings when he was at dinner with us. 
“I just tried to get a feeling of what he felt and what he wanted in life. And I can remember quite vividly him saying to me ‘I just need somebody to give me a chance, I need somebody to give me a lucky break’. 
“After that - maybe three or four weeks later - I actually employed him. After long consultation with my management team, we decided that we would like to help him, so I employed him at one of the businesses that I run down in Newport in south Wales." How Aaron Barley 'went off the rails' after taking drugs 
“In September 2016 he went off the rails. He started taking drugs and as a business we had to let him go. It was very amicable. He knew that that was the case because of what he’d been doing. Tracey Wilkinson and her son Pierce, 13, were murdered by Aaron Barley, right Credit: SWNS 
“He actually said at the time that he had started taking drugs because his mother had died, which was subsequently found to be untrue.” 
A sked if he had noticed a change in Barley’s personality during that time, Mr Wilkinson added: “I would say we had seen a change but a change conversant with something that you might expect to see if somebody had been taking drugs - not a change in his general persona." Finding him 'asleep like a bundle on the drive' 
"I remember in late October or early November coming back from walking the dog one of the mornings and finding him asleep like a bundle in the corner of the drive. 
“I got him up and made him some tea. I believe he’d been on the streets and had been badly beaten. He was covered in bruises and my wife being the compassionate soul that she was, decided that as a family we should help him again. 
“In a similar vein to what we had done last time, we managed to get accommodation for him. We paid for some accommodation ourselves for him. Aaron Barley (right) in the dock at Birmingham Crown Court Credit: Elizabeth Cook/PA 
“My wife wouldn’t see him back on the streets so over the next couple of weeks we managed to get council accommodation sorted. 
“And he would do general jobs for us, for other members of my family as well, in order to earn some pocket money for food and cigarettes. And he was generally very grateful. Spending Christmas Day with the killer 
“From that point onwards, I think through ’til Christmas he’d got some part-time work or some cash-in-hand work. And then at Christmas last year he spent Christmas Day with us. 
“He had Christmas lunch with us. I remember he wrote my wife a card saying ‘To the mother that I never had’. My wife was very caring and he treated her a bit like a second mother." 'We shared a curry... next time I saw him he was stabbing me' 
“He then, in January, got some full-time work. He’d got a new flat. We were very happy for him. We still saw him then once or twice a week - he would come for dinner. 
“And then in early March, he came round one night - the last time I saw him. I bought a curry and I shared a curry and a couple of bottles of beer with him. I dropped him off back at his flat in Brierley Hill that night. 
"And that was it for about three weeks - the next time I saw him he was sticking a knife into my shoulder.” The attacks: He was dressed in black, with a big knife above his head 
A sked what he could remember of the attack upon him, Mr Wilkinson said: “I did my normal thing of going out to take the dog for a walk. 
"I came back and I can remember looking through the window at the back door of the house, thinking that everybody must have overslept because nobody was up. 
“I opened the back door and as I did it, he jumped out from behind a wall in the kitchen, all dressed in black, with a big knife held over his head and started stabbing me with it. Police officers outside the Wilkinson family home in Stourbridge Credit: Joe Giddens/PA 
“From that point I grappled with him for a short period of time and he stabbed me six times - he stabbed me twice in the face, twice in the abdomen and twice in the back. 
“I thought he was going to carry on stabbing me, but I then heard my car going off the drive - we have got a gravel drive and the crunch of the car going off it was quite distinctive. 
“I got up, I think I was on the lawn at this time. I got up, went into the kitchen and phoned the emergency services, at the time not thinking I was too badly injured." 'I was actually dying... I could feel energy draining from me' 
“Then I remember looking around and seeing this huge trail of blood across the floor, which was my blood. I then went back out into the back garden, sat in a chair and I remember talking to the person on the other end of the phone and realising that I was actually dying. 
"I could feel my lungs filling with fluid and I could feel energy draining from me. 
“The next thing I remember is ambulances turning up and I can remember hearing helicopters overhead and the police arrived. 
“An ambulance man tended to me immediately. I remember him jabbing something into me, which is probably what kept me alive. Peter Wilkinson and daughter Lydia relieve their ordeal Credit: Aaron Chown/PA 
“I also remember telling the other ambulance men to go into the house. I remember vividly one coming out behind me and saying ‘one deceased and one in cardiac arrest’. I knew at that point that I had most likely lost Tracey and Pierce. Then I was taken to the QE.” 
A sked to describe his feelings at that time, Mr Wilkinson said: “I thought I was going to die at that stage. I remember being in the back of the ambulance on the way to hospital. I could feel every bump. I remember getting to the QE and being rushed in and then general anaesthetic being administered and waking up whenever I woke up.” Wife was 'a beautiful woman with a heart of gold' 
Paying his own tributes, Mr Wilkinson said: “My wife was a beautiful woman with a heart of gold. She was stylish, she was elegant. She was very compassionate. 
“She cared for others and it’s just so tragic that after trying to help people and to help Aaron, that he should turn on us in this way for no apparent reason.” Tracey Wilkinson was murdered in March last year Credit: West Midlands Police/PA On the murderer: 'I wish my wife had never set eyes on him' 
A sked to comment on his feelings towards Barley, Mr Wilkinson added: “I wish we had never met him - I wish my wife had never set eyes on him.” 
Commenting on his physical condition now, he added: “I was in hospital for 11 nights. I’m ok. I had a lot of wounds and stitches but the physical scars will heal, the mental scars never will. 
“Lydia has been my absolute rock. She’s everything to me. We do lots and lots of things together, we always have done. We are a very close family. 
“We are still a very close family but we are two people instead of four. Lydia’s fortitude and strength and her love for me is beyond belief.” Pierce Wilkinson, 13, died after the attack at home Credit: West Midlands Police/PA 'He said ‘die you b ’ as he stuck the knife into me'

posts.text:
Fred Heffer 3 October 2017 • 2:43pm 
O n Wednesday (October 4) the 61st BFI London Film Festival begins. Over 12 days more than 200 films will be screened, representing more than 60 countries as part of the official programme. From projects by established directors to under-the-radar efforts, here are some of the most exciting entries to look forward to this year. 1. Three Billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri Woody Harrelson with Frances McDormand Credit: Fox Searchlight 
M artin McDonagh's (In Bruges, Seven Psycopaths) latest crime film has been delighting festival audiences this year, and should do the same in London. Frances McDormand plays a distraught mother whose police-shaming tactics (the titular billboards) regarding their failure to investigate her daughter's killing earn her the hostility of Woody Harrelson's chief and many of the townsfolk. Expect vigilantism and justice themes worthy of the Coens or Tarantino. Read our review here . 2. Breathe Andrew Garfield and Claire Foy in Andy Serkis's Breathe Credit: Bleecker Street 
A ndy Serkis's directorial debut - and the LFF's opening film - concerns the true story of Robin Cavendish (Andrew Garfield), a young polio victim who becomes a globe-trotting champion of the disabled. His family and friends come to support him in his new calling, including his wife (Claire Foy), her twin brothers (Tom Hollander) and the inventor of Cavendish's specialised wheelchair (Hugh Bonneville). 3. Battle of the Sexes Emma Stone and Steve Carell Credit: Fox Searchlight 
F ittingly this sports drama is made by husband-and-wife team Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris (who also directed Little Miss Sunshine). Steve Carell and Emma Stone are tennis players Bobby Riggs and Billie Jean King, who faced off in a 1973 exhibition match to determine whether the greatest female players could beat even aging male pros. At the same time, it details King's issues with her own sexuality and Riggs's career-end discontent. Watch the trailer here . 4. Downsizing Credit: Paramount 
M att Damon and Kristen Wiig star as a couple who join in this sci-fi film's subject matter: shrinking oneself to live more economically and sustainably. Although the changed perspective of being five inches tall offers an escape from everyday stresses, it comes with its own problems, and not everyone appears to be getting shrunk willingly. Read our review here . 5. The Killing of a Sacred Deer Colin Farrell stars in Yorgos Lanthimos's film Credit: A24 
I n this psychological horror film, Colin Farrell plays Steven Murphy, a hyper-competent cardiovascular specialist with an equally an successful family life. The only way is down. He begins looking out for Martin, a troubled teenager played by Barry Keoghan (of "I'll be useful" fame in Dunkirk), who returns the favour by causing chaos in Murphy's Nicole Kidman-starring domestic life. Is the boy the source of all these problems, or does the surgeon have something to hide? Read our review here . 6. Last Flag Flying Bryan Cranston, Steve Carell and Laurence Fishburne in Last Flag Flying Credit: Amazon Studios/Lionsgate 
A comedy-drama from Richard Linklater, this is an adaptation of a 2005 novel by Darryl Ponicsan. Steve Carell, Bryan Cranston and Laurence Fishburne play Vietnam veteran friends who reunite after Carell's son is killed in Iraq. The trio embark on a road trip along the East Coast as they transport the coffin home, leaving time for reflection among the group on their own years of service and the time intervening. 7. Brigsby Bear Kyle Mooney is a kidnapping victim in Brigsby Bear Credit: Sony Pictures Classics 
C laire Danes, Mark Hamill and the Lonely Island's Andy Samberg are among the cast in this film about one of the weirder paths Stockholm Syndrome can take. Kyle Mooney plays James Pope, a man who learns that his "parents" abducted him as a child. Unable to cope with his new life, he finds comfort in the adventures of a childhood hero, the TV character Brigsby Bear. When the bear's existence also turns out to have been an elaborate trick by his kidnappers, James sets out to introduce the world to his ursine companion and continue filming the show, even if it means going up against the police. 8. My Friend Dahmer Ross Lynch as a young Jeffrey Dahmer Credit: FilmRise 
B efore Jeffrey Dahmer came to fame as the "Milwaukee Cannibal" he was your average off-beat high schooler. Just ask his classmate John Backderf, whose graphic novel became the basis for Marc Meyers's film. Intentionally given the feel of a Napoleon Dynamite imitator, the movie's dark but humorous tone shifts massively to the former as Dahmer's depraved sexual and social attitudes are awakened. The director deliberately cast the lead role against type to increase the shock-Ross Lynch is most famous for playing a wholesome musician in the Disney show Austin & Ally. 9. Sicilian Ghost Story Credit: Indigo Film 
S icily is not under-represented in Mafia movies, but it has been in fantasy Mafia movies, until now. A young girl searches for her classmate when he disappears near a forest. In reality he's been kidnapped by mobsters, but the girl's search for him takes her through a realm of pure fantasy. It's Pan's Labyrinth via Gomorrah. 10. Wonderstruck Julianne Moore in Wonderstruck Credit: Amazon Studios/Roadside Attraction 
B ased on a novel by the author Brian Selznick, the story takes place in two time periods with seemingly unrelated stories. In 1927, a girl named Rose obsessively follows an actress's career. Fifty years later, the Midwestern child Ben longs for his absent father. Then both their paths start leading together. Featuring Julianne Moore . 11. Thoroughbreds Credit: Focus Features 
O livia Cooke and Anya Taylor-Joy play Connecticut teenagers Amanda and Lily, who reform their friendship after years apart. One is well-educated and set up in life, the other has become a cynical loner. In spite of these differences they bond again over shared dislikes, including Lily's hatred for her stepfather. But talking things through with him isn't what their re-assessment of the world is building to. 
The film also features the last screen performance by the late Anton Yelchin as a local criminal whose services are called upon by the pair to assist their plans. 12. Le Redoutable Louis Garrel and Stacy Martin Credit: StudioCanal 
M ichel Hazanavicius (director of The Artist ) has made this film about an eventful period in the life of his compatriot Jean Luc-Godard. The year is 1967 and the Frenchman is in a good place: he has already made a name for himself and he's about to marry the 17-year old actress Anne Wiazemsky (on whose autobiography this film is partly based). The upheavals of 1968 are about to test their relationship however, as will Godard's transformation from an easygoing artist to a politically-driven filmmaker as he sets about producing La Chinoise. 13. Memoir of a Murderer Credit: Showbox/Mediaplex 
M ost people's knowledge of Korean cinema begins and ends with Oldboy, and if you liked that this film won't take you too far from your comfort zone. Sul Kyung-Ju plays Byung-su, a serial murderer "retired" by Alzheimer's and cared for by his adoptive daughter. She introduces her new boyfriend, whom Byung-su recognises as a fellow killer and sets out to thwart his plans. But how reliable is his memory?

Hannah Strange , in Barcelona 3 October 2017 • 2:47pm 
A union of Spain’s Guardia Civil called on Tuesday for urgent reinforcements in Catalonia, accusing the government in Madrid of “abandoning” them to “harassment” it said had reached the level of ETA’s heyday. 
Amid anger on Catalan streets over the violent police crackdown on Sunday’s banned independence referendum which left almost 900 injured, the Union of Guardia Civil Officers said agents were being “harassed, manipulated and vilified by the citizens that they serve”. 
Hundreds of National Police and Guardia Civil officers have been forced to abandon Catalan hotels in the face of protests by local residents, while thousands of demonstrators descended on the National Police headquarters in Barcelona on Wednesday. 
“Right now Catalonia is like the Basque Country in 1981,” it said in a blistering statement which claimed they had been “abandoned to their luck” by government “inaction” and “betrayed” by “disloyal” Catalan police, the Mossos d’Esquadra. 
1981 was a particularly violent period in the Basque conflict and the year of a major crisis in post-dictatorship Spain, which saw an attempted coup by members of the army and Guardia Civil partly in response to the intensifying ETA offensive during the transition to democracy. Thousands of citizens gather in Plaza Universitat during a regional general strike to protest against the violence that marred Sunday's referendum vote on October 3 Credit: David Ramos/ Getty Images Europe 
C arles Puigdemont, the Catalan president, on Monday demanded the government in Madrid withdraw the thousands of officers deployed for the vote. But ministers have not blinked, and on Tuesday it was reported that the two cruise liners housing officers in the port of Barcelona had extended their stay until October 11. 
The Guardia Civil union, however, said the government must “look after them, or pull them out”. 
"The lamentable incidents that right now are taking place in Catalonia, where the forces and bodies of state security are surrounded in hotels, abandoned to their luck, betrayed by some disloyal Mossos d'Esquadra, encouraged by politicians (that are) TRAITORS to the state, witnessing live on Whatsapp the lynching of our fellow Guardia Civil, do not leave us any other course than to ask that action is taken, that they are liberated, that they are reinforced, that they are assisted, that decisions are taken,” the union said. Firefighters protest in Barcelona amid a general strike called in Catalonia, Spain Credit: ALEJANDRO GARCIA/EFE 
N ational Police unions too called protests outside the force’s stations across Spain, with five organizations calling on the Spanish Interior Ministry to enact “urgent and effective measures” to guarantee officers’ security in Catalonia. 
In a joint statement, they demanded ministers “stop passing the buck” and “back with actions, not words, the work of the only officials who in this moment are maintaining the rule of law in Catalonia”. 
The interior minister, Juan Ignacio Zoido, called a crisis meeting, insisting he would take “all necessary measures to halt the intolerable harassment” of security forces. 
The National Police also rounded on the Mossos d’Esquadra, which has drawn heavy criticism from national authorities for failing to take a hardline approach to Sunday’s vote. Catalan Independence supporters celebrate as '90pc of voters' say yes 01:13 
T he unions claimed: “the work of the Mossos d’Esquadra … remains dominated by inaction, laxness, neutrality and the aversion to the fulfillment of their legal obligations”. 
Police forces including the Mossos had received judicial orders to close polling stations and prevent voting, but "without affecting the normal coexistence of the citizens". 
The Catalan force, citing public safety, took a hands-off approach, which national security forces allege forced the crackdown that has drawn opprobrium from around the world. Alarmingly, in several instances, disagreements between the Catalan and national officers also erupted into physical aggression. Citizens march with a Catalan flag during a regional general strike outside the Sagrada Familia Credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images Europe 
T he European Parliament is to debate the Catalonia crisis on Wednesday after criticism of the EU Commission for failing to condemn the police violence, which saw rubber bullets fired into crowds, women dragged from polling stations by their hair and pensioners left with head wounds. 
The United Nations’ top human rights official has demanded access for investigators, while international observers reported witnessing “events that no election monitors ought to ever witness”. 
The Catalan government has announced its own commission to investigate acts of police violence. 
Joan Maria Piqué, a government spokesman, roundly dismissed the complaints of national security forces today, telling the Telegraph that after “the Spanish police aggression on defenceless people who only wanted to vote in peace, those statements are just cynical and heartless. The images are out there for the world to see.” Related Topics

Jack Maidment , Political Correspondent 3 October 2017 • 2:47pm 
C riminals who take part in armed robberies are “stupid” because they could use the internet to commit crime without the risk of getting shot, the Security Minister has said . 
Ben Wallace said anyone who tried to rob a bank was likely to be killed or caught - either by the police or a “local gangster”. 
He said they could instead buy software on the “dark web” to “try and defraud hundreds of thousands of people” from the comfort of their own home. 
His comments risked accusations of giving career advice to criminals. 
Mr Wallace also warned that cyber crime was a “growing threat” as he urged people to remain vigilant online and to be alert to con artists who try to fool people into handing over their bank details. Ben Wallace, the Security Minister Credit: John Stillwell/PA 
S peaking at a fringe event at Conservative Party conference in Manchester, Mr Wallace said: “Cyber crime is growing, it is the new crime in that sense and we must learn to change with it. 
“You would be pretty stupid nowadays to be an armed robber. You are likely, if you are an armed robber, to be caught. 
"You are likely to be shot. You are likely to be caught fencing the money should you actually make it out of the bank and you are likely to probably be shot by the local gangster who doesn’t like you doing it in his patch. 
“Whereas you can sit at home, go on the dark web, buy an off the shelf malware kit for £10, a mailing list on the internet for another £10 and you can sit in your bedroom and happily try and defraud hundreds of thousands of people. 
“That is a real, growing threat and we have to encourage our police to invest in that part of policing, but work together.” 
Mr Wallace said changing passwords and maintaining anti-virus software were two ways in which people could stay safe online as he also stressed the importance of remaining vigilant to offline threats. 
He said everyone should learn the “tell-tale signs” of terrorism to help the security services and the police foil plots. Cyber crime | Most common UK online offences 
H e said: “In the physical space with the terrorism threat and the organised crime threat, if you see something suspicious, act on it. 
“Take time to be aware of your surroundings and in the current threat of what we call sudden violent extremists, a suicide attack or a person coming in with a knife, think about, as crude as this, your exits. 
“Think about how you could get out of a building if something happens and you are in a crowded space.” 
He said that all terrorists “leave signs”. 
“When I look at the incidents that we have had and I look through the post-incident evidence, they all leave signs and some of those signs could have been spotted by the public and that is important for us to all learn the tell tale signs that give people away,” he said. Related Topics

thread.title: EU banks are not taking Brexit risks seriously enough, warns BoE

posts.author: Tim Wallace
posts.title: EU banks are not taking Brexit risks seriously enough, warns BoE
posts.text:
Tim Wallace 3 October 2017 • 3:10pm 
E uropean banks are underprepared for Brexit and could lose access to the City of London if they do not move quickly to apply for a UK banking licence, a Bank of England committee has warned. 
Officials at the Bank are pushing lenders to sharpen up their contingency plans as their branches in Britain could lose the right to operate after March 2019. 
This is crucial both to the UK and the EU economies as London is the centre of European capital markets. 
If foreign banks lose access to Britain - because their regulations cut them off from funds and banks outside the EU - it risks causing immense disruption to the continent, starving businesses of the funds they need to invest and grow. Deutsche Bank has signed a new 25-year commitment to office space in London, but not all EU banks have been quite so on the ball after the Brexit vote Credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images 
E U banks also provide around 10pc of the corporate lending used by companies in Britain, so securing a continuation of their services in the UK is valuable for domestic purposes too. 
“The risk of disruption to wholesale UK banking services appeared to be slightly higher than previously thought, given that a number of European Economic Area (EEA) firms branching into the UK were not sufficiently focused on addressing this issue,” said the Bank of England’s Financial Policy Committee (FPC) in the record of its latest meeting. 
“Absent an appropriate agreement in place at the point of exit, EEA firms branching into the UK would need to apply for new authorisations from the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) in order to continue to carry out regulated activities here.” 
Those banks need to start their applications before the end of the first quarter of 2018, and the Bank is pushing them to do so: “The PRA was engaging firms to improve the state of their contingency planning.” 
Last week the PRA’s boss Sam Woods said he expected that around 130 banks would need to apply for licences to continue operating in the UK. Sam Woods said he expects around 130 EU banks will need to apply Credit: Jonathan Brady/PA 
O fficials are also concerned about the future of cross-border insurance after Brexit, as well as the implications for companies that send personal data across borders. 
“Loss of authorisation could affect firms’ ability to continue to collect premiums and pay out on claims on outstanding insurance contracts, which in some cases extend for several years,” the FPC said. 
“Firms also lacked robust contingency plans to mitigate risks to financial service provision from possible barriers to the flow of personal data between the UK and EU27. Many firms currently relied on datacentres located in the United Kingdom to provide financial services across Europe.” 
This can be resolved only if the EU and the UK come to an agreement on operations across borders, the Bank of England said. 
“The continued free flow of personal data would require the United Kingdom and EU27 to recognise each other’s data protection regimes as ‘adequate’,” the FPC said.

posts.title: Sending naked pictures is now a hallmark of society, judge says
posts.text:
A judge declared sending naked pictures to prospective partners is now a "hallmark of society" as he jailed a man for repeatedly sending revenge porn .
Daniel Stainton, 26, of Cheltenham, admitted blackmailing three young women who sent him naked pictures of themselves after meeting him on social media.
Passing sentence, Judge Jamie Tabor QC said: "Whatever trust these ladies had in men has disappeared, unsurprisingly.
"It is a hallmark of our society now that young women and sometimes young men - and sometimes mature people - exchange such photographs. All well and good.
"But what people do not appear to appreciate is that these images are not gone in a moment - they can hang around, as we can see in this case, for years.
"There came a time in your life when you were hard up for money and decided to embark on this campaign of blackmail. The effect on the women was dramatic and horrible. You had no regard at all for your victims."
What you need to know | Revenge porn T he court heard one of the victims paid him almost £1,000 not to go public with the intimate pictures of herself, Gloucester Crown Court was told.
Stainton, who pleaded guilty to disclosing private sexual photographs with intent to cause distress, was jailed for five years and three months.
Richard Posner, prosecuting, said all three victims were left feeling "degraded, humiliated and traumatised".
Mr Posner told the court the blackmailing went on over a 12 week period from December 2016 to February this year.
"His actions showed evidence of planning by the retention of these intimate images and a degree of targeting. The impact of his crimes on his victims is significant," Mr Posner said.
It is a hallmark of our society now that young women and sometimes young men - and sometimes mature people - exchange such photographs. All well and good Judge Jamie Tabor QC "He seems to have been motivated by greed, which demonstrates a high level of deviancy and manipulation."
V ictim A was a 26-year-old shop worker from Cheltenham who met Stainton in 2012 and thought he was a "nice guy, a shoulder to cry on" when her marriage started to break down, Mr Posner said.
"From March 2013 they became close. She sent him two photos of herself naked via WhatsApp. She then decided to leave her husband for the defendant - but he immediately sent her husband a text telling him that she had been cheating on him.
"She says this broke her heart and she lost all contact with the defendant."
Then in 2016 he contacted her on Instagram, using a different name and asking to be a friend. She accepted. But he then sent her four photographs of women, one of them the intimate shot of herself.
"When she contacted the defendant he claimed the message was nothing to do with him and that he had lost the phone with her pictures on it." said the prosecutor.
"On 31st December last year he contacted her from yet another Instagram account, threatening that unless she paid him £400 he had pictures that she would not want her husband to see. She called the defendant again and he still denied it was him.
"She said she would call the police and the Instagram account he had used was then deleted. She never gave in to the demands and lost no money."
Mr Posner said Victim B was a 21 year old sales assistant in Scotland.
"She started to chat online with the defendant towards the end of October 2016 and she sent him intimate photographs. One was topless.
"They exchanged about five or six naked images. She sent them through Snapchat. Unknown to her, the defendant took screenshots of these images before they disappeared.
"We say he was collecting these images to exploit her later if he decided to do so. Last December he contacted her and demanded money or he would post the pictures online if she didn't pay him.
"For two months he extorted money from her. He said he would send the pictures to her family and friends if she did not pay.
"On 7th December she paid him £200. On 16th December she paid another £175. On 16th January this year she paid £200. On 8th February she paid him £300.
"The defendant continue to ask for more money and she then reported him to the police. He then posted an intimate picture of her naked on her timeline on Facebook but fortunately she was able to delete it immediately."
Victim C, now in her early twenties, was only 15 when she was first in contact with Stainton on Facebook sometime before 2011, Mr Poster said.
"They chatted online and exchanged numbers. After several months he asked for a naked picture of herself. She was not comfortable with that. He asked for a topless picture instead.
"Under some pressure she sent him one but her head was not in the photograph. "
When Stainton was jailed in July 2011 for dishonesty offences he called the girl and told her - and then started writing to her from prison, the prosecutor said.
"He asked for more topless photographs but she declined. On 22nd January this year, using an Instagram account called 'Culture&Cars', he told her to bring £300 in cash and to leave it in an envelope under a bin in a park or he would upload the topless image.
"The young lady was left scared, wondering how many other people would see it. She told her parents. They decided to call the police. "
Stainton has seven previous criminal convictions for 19 offences, added Mr Posner.
Stainton's Scottish victim said in a statement: "He threatened to expose my photographs on social media to all my friends and family. I was terrified by this blackmail.
"I borrowed money to pay his demands. I had suicidal thoughts. I need to take time off work. I was left broken. He just didn't seem to care. He was just wanting money. I felt worthless."
A statement from Victim A said she felt nauseous when she received the blackmail demand and she was "shaking and crying".
Mr Posner said: "This has left her feeling degraded and humiliated. It has triggered panic attacks. She suffers nightmares.
"She states 'This person is has completely destroyed my confidence in people."
Victim C stated: "This has made me feel depressed, self-conscious and anxious. I am scared to go out because because I feel ashamed. I was betrayed by someone I classed as a friend who I thought I could trust."
William Rose, defending, said: "There is nothing I can say which excuses or justifies his behaviour. The best mitigation I have is that he has pleaded guilty at the first opportunity.
"He has written letters, one addressed to Your Honour and three to the victims. He would like them to know he is genuinely sorry.
"It was all down to money and his desperation to try to retain his accommodation. He had arrears of rent and was facing eviction. These ladies became victims because of his greed."

posts.title: Bob Diamond's Atlas Mara co-founder steps down amid board rejig
posts.text:
Lucy Burton , Financial services editor 3 October 2017 • 3:20pm 
T he Atlas Mara co-founder once dubbed Africa's youngest billionaire is stepping down from the board of the business he set up with former Barclays boss Bob Diamond amid a rejig of seats. 
Ashish Thakkar, who set up Mara Group in 1996 at the age of 15, co-founded the African investment company in 2013 shortly after Mr Diamond left Barclays amid the Libor-rigging scandal. 
His move away from the board follows a deal struck with investment company Fairfax Africa earlier this year, which stipulated that Fairfax would be handed four of Atlas Mara's nine board seats. 
A person close to the group said the 36-year old, who has been embroiled in a high-profile divorce battle this year over assets that include a Virgin Galactic space ticket, volunteered to step down as a result of the deal as did another of the group's founding directors, Tonye Cole. 
As co-founder, Mr Thakkar - who describes himself on Twitter as a "refugee, school dropout, entrepreneur, astronaut, philanthropist & now author" - will still be involved in advising the company on key areas such as government relations. 
The change took place with immediate effect, with Atlas Mara immediately updating its website on Tuesday to list new board members Michael Wilkerson, Richard Boucher, Quinn McLean and Hisham Ezz Al-Arab. 
The firm sold a stake to Fairfax in a bid to raise $200m, sealing the deal not long after it promised to slash operating costs by $20m a year . Shares in the firm have fallen 70pc since its London listing in 2013, with the group rattled by a plunge in commodity prices as well as a fall in African currencies against the dollar. thread.title: Donald Trump heads to Puerto Rico amid criticism over handling of hurricane crisis
thread.title_full: Donald Trump heads to Puerto Rico amid criticism over handling of hurricane crisis

posts.author: Harriet Alexander
posts.title: Donald Trump heads to Puerto Rico amid criticism over handling of hurricane crisis
posts.text:
D onald Trump visited hurricane-ravaged Puerto Rico on Tuesday, where he remarked that officials should be “proud” because the death toll was not as high as “a real catastrophe” like Hurricane Katrina.
Mr Trump and his wife Melania were briefed on relief efforts, after the president noted as he landed that the hurricane had "thrown our budget out of whack".
“If you look at a real catastrophe like Katrina, and you look at the hundreds and hundreds of people that died - what is your death count? Sixteen. You can be very proud of all of your people,” he said. 
Doctors, however, warn that significant numbers of people are at now risk of dying from treatable diseases because they cannot access their routine prescriptions.
There is also growing concern about the spread of disease on an island which still is largely without power, a fortnight after Hurricane Maria hit, and where mountain communities remain flooded and largely cut off.
Mr Trump visited the affluent district of Guaynabo, telling a family who showed him their damaged home to “have a good time”, before heading to a community centre distributing aid, where he tossed rolls of toilet paper into the crowd.
Puerto Rican radio talk shows were dominated by discussion of Mr Trump's throwing of paper towels. Some called it humiliating and insulting, watching people bussed in from shelters having lost their homes leap for toilet paper.
But those inside the church thought it was fun. "It was really entertaining," said Benjamin Rodríguez, 24, a youth leader at the church. Natisa Marrero, 28, an administrator at the church, added: "He's a character. It's just who he is. Everyone thought it was funny. And anyway, he was only here for a few minutes."
Mr Trump and Melania Trump arrive on Air Force One Credit: Joe Raedle/Getty A t the Calvary Chapel, in a basement underneath a strip mall, Mr Trump handed out torches. "But you don't need these now," he said, commenting on how he believed the power had been restored.
Officials in the church told The Telegraph afterwards that the church itself had no electricity, and was running on a generator. The neighbouring hospital, the Centro Médico, did have power restored, they said. But the struggling system failed again after two days, leaving that too to rely on a generator.
Earlier, Mr Trump thanked the navy chiefs, telling them he had witnessed their efforts as his plane came down to land.
"I saw them flying in and I said, boy, this looks like very big stuff," he said.
"There are no docks, no nothing, and the way you got this on shore is incredible."
Mr Trump has been criticised over his response to the hurricane and accused of inaction in the immediate aftermath .
The president appeared unaware that the Crowley port terminal in San Juan, contracted by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), was reopened three days after the storm.
He asked Jenniffer Gonzalez Colon, who represents Puerto Rico in Congress, to say again some of the “very nice things” she had said about relief efforts.
Ricardo Rossello, governor of Puerto Rico, then thanked Mr Trump for his support.
Mr Trump and Melania Trump prepare to leave Washington, DC for the hurricane-hit island Credit: Reuters "This is a united effort. We need to work together to overcome the many challenges we have here," he said.
"Over the course of the past week you have called essentially every day.
Y ou have always responded to us. We are convinced that working together – it is a challenging time, we need to do more – but we will make Puerto Rico stronger than ever before."
The officials around the table clapped enthusiastically - all except Carmen Yulin Cruz, mayor of San Juan, who sat with her hands clasped in front of her. 
The pair, who sparred on Twitter over the weekend, had exchanged pleasantries before the meeting.
Mr Trump then set off to visit the island, meeting some of those affected by the disaster in the capital, San Juan, before visiting the Cavalry Chapel in Guaynabo – one of the most affluent areas of the city.
He will then board the USS Kearsarge, an amphibious assault ship home to 1,893 marines, for meetings with Mr Rossello and Kenneth Mapp, governor of the US Virgin Islands.
The president and his wife landed on an island whose basic infrastructure was almost entirely wiped out a fortnight ago by Maria - the worst storm in 90 years.
There is still no power; half the 3.4 million people do not have running water; 65 per cent are without communications; and almost 9,000 have been forced from their homes.
Puerto Ricans hope that Mr Trump’s visit will further open his eyes to the misery.
The president has some previous association with the island. Four years ago it was home to one of his golf courses.
“We’re part of the US; he’s our president, so we welcome his arrival,” said Jason Matos, the superintendent at the course once known as Trump International Golf Club.
San Juan mayor focused on 'saving lives' not Trump row 01:05 “He’s said so much about how he cares. So now he has to show it.”
M r Trump managed the golf course from 2008 until 2015, when the resort – struggling before he took it on – finally declared bankruptcy.
The Trump Organization walked away with more than $600,000 in revenue from the management and licensing deal. Eric Trump said after the bankruptcy filing: “We made many millions of dollars on it but never invested a dime.”
He later insisted the Trump involvement was minimal.
"We merely licensed our name for a fee and have nothing to do with the ownership, development or entity," said Eric.
Harriet Alexander dispatch: Aid crisis in Puerto Rico 01:31 N ow renamed the Coco Beach golf course, the 36-hole resort, at the foot of the mountains that make up El Yunque rainforest national park, 20 miles east of the capital, has been closed since the hurricane.
But the greens are clear, and Roberto Delgado, the tournament coordinator, hopes it will reopen soon. He too said Mr Trump’s visit was positive.
Carlos Esteves’s house overlooks what were once Mr Trump’s greens. An army veteran, he now works for the coast guard in the marine inspection division, and said the visit of his “boss” was welcome.
“I think it’ll improve morale,” he said. “I would like to see more resources coming in from the mainland , but I think at the same time we need more guidance on how to get it around.
“I’m a military man and I can tell you for a fact that the 192nd support battalion from the national guard has plenty of equipment, plenty of fuel, and desalination plants.”
Asked why they are not being used, and he looks at the sky and starts whistling – diplomatically refusing to weigh in.
Puerto Rico student rescues 90 birds from Hurricane Maria 00:23 A few doors down Charlie Robles is helping his son Emmanuel load a barrel of water into his truck, to drive to Emmanuel’s home in Fajardo.
Mr Robles’s house has running water; his son’s does not.
“We’re US citizens, but we’re not getting the help that other US citizens do,” he said. “I don’t like Trump, but if he comes and sees and makes things better, then that’s good.”
Ricky Blazquez, a 25-year-old engineering student, said he hoped Mr Trump’s visit would improve the situation. But he was taking no chances, and had taken matters into his own hands.
People walk next to a petrol station flooded and damaged by the impact of Hurricane Maria Credit: AP F or the past five days Mr Blazquez has been queuing up at the petrol station to fill canisters and share them out among his neighbours. He has bought 100-150 gallons a day, he believes.
“I have been working with my community to get things better here, because Maria hit us hard,” he said.
“First I filled up my own, and then people asked me for help, so I gave them some and went back for more.
“It was never a plan, but just ended up that way.”
He hoped Tuesday’s visit will raise spirits.
“It’s very important because everyone is despondent here. So I think it’ll make us do better.”

posts.author: Telegraph Reporters
posts.title: 'I was facing triple funeral - then Dad came round': Daughter's heartbreaking account of murder in her own words
posts.text:
Telegraph Reporters 3 October 2017 • 3:37pm 
L ydia Wilkinson was faced with the prospect of planning a triple funeral alone as she feared her father would die from his injuries in the days after he was stabbed by a homeless man. 
The 19-year-old had been due to return to Stourbridge to see her family a day after the senseless murder of her mother and brother - but instead found herself rushing to Birmingham's Queen Elizabeth Hospital. 
The biology student, who recently began her second year of studies at Bristol University, was told to expect the worst after arriving at her father's bedside and seeing him under sedation. 
Miss Wilkinson arrived at the hospital at about 5pm, around three hours after she learned her mother and brother had died. In her own words, Lydia Wilkinson describes her family's ordeal 
"They took me to critical care and that was the first time I saw my dad - with countless machines hooked up to him, a lot of doctors around his bed," she said in a media interview organised through West Midlands Police. 
"I remember thinking at that point in time that I was going to lose him as well because nobody could survive that state." 
"I was told that my dad was still in theatre when I found out (about the stabbings) because I found out from my boyfriend ringing me to check if my family were OK." Tracey Wilkinson and her son Pierce, 13, were murdered by Aaron Barley, right Credit: SWNS How she saw picture of police at the family home 
R ecounting how she found out initial details of what had happened at around 10.30am on March 30, Miss Wilkinson said: "I remember typing into Google 'Stourbridge, stabbings'. 
"The first link showed a photo of my house with police tape around it. I remember ringing my boyfriend back and saying, 'It's me, it's us, they've been stabbed'. Police outside the Wilkinson family home in Stourbridge last March Credit: Joe Giddens/PA 
"I then proceeded to go into a friend's room, where we called the police and asked if this was real or not, if it was me. 
"They sent over officers to my halls of residence in Bristol. My phone was taken off me so that I couldn't find out online. 
"They said, 'We are very sorry to tell you that your mum and brother have passed away and your dad is in theatre and we don't know whether he will survive or not, we have had no news'." 'Dad was the only thing I had left in life' 
S he said of her father: "I thought he was going to pass away that night. 
"I knew there was nothing I could do to help my mum and Pierce as they had tragically passed away, so my sole focus at that moment in time was my dad, because he was the only thing I had left in life. 
"And if I didn't have him then I was going to be completely on my own and there was nothing I could do about it. 
"So I stayed with him for a long time. I remember the doctors said that he was under heavy sedation and wouldn't come round. 
"But I held his hand much like I am doing now and said that I was there and he opened his eyes and looked at me and then went back unconscious. Peter Wilkinson, who survived the attack, and daughter Lydia, hold hands as they speak about their loss Credit: Aaron Chown/PA 
"He woke up later on that evening, just as I had gone back to my boyfriend's house, who I stayed with for a few weeks. 
"I remember coming back in the car from Bristol to the Queen Elizabeth. I was planning a triple funeral and how I was going to go about that on my own. 
"And from that moment on when he started to come round, I did start to hope that he was going to be OK. 
"There were ups and down over the next few days but I didn't truly believe he was going to make it until maybe the third or fourth day." On support they have received from friends 
“We have been truly astounded by people's support. That even continues to this day, even though it’s six months on. 
"And we genuinely couldn’t do that without that support and if we could thank everyone, we would. I remember receiving a letter at my faculty building in Bristol from a man in London, whom I had never met before, that the story touched. Pierce Wilkinson (left), his sister Lydia Wilkinson and his father Peter Wilkinson Credit: HGRGT/PA 
"It’s things like that help you through. Because there is always somebody who cares. We are caring people and we still are. That is always going to be in our nature. So the support that is around is just phenomenal. 
“I have returned to university, have started my second year of Biology and we continue to stay strong, and be resilient and we are determined to not let this take away any more of our life. Returning home - and what the future holds 
"The two closest people of our family have been taken away from us and we are not going to let it go any further, which is why we returned home to the house that we love and I have gone back to study a subject that I love. 
"I’d like to be a researcher and do medical research, to continue the help and support that my mum would give to people. 
"By researching things like cancer and Parkinson's Disease I hope to give back to people and continue her legacy."

posts.text:
A women-only Cambridge University college has changed its policy to allow any students who "identify" as female to apply.
Until this year, Murray Edwards college required all applicants to be “legally defined as female”. But now the college’s council has approved an update to its entry criteria, stating that it will accept any student “who at the point of application identifies as a woman”.
The college, whose alumni include Sue Perkins, Claudia Winkelman and Tilda Swinton, states on its website that “with so much gender inequality still in the world there is a role for a College able to focus on outstanding young women, their learning and skills for life."
The change was made after a motion on transgender was passed by the College Council, a group of academics and teaching fellows.
In a statement published after the vote, the council stated that it has “sympathy with the idea that gender is not binary” and that “narrow gender identities” are damaging to “wider society”.
Its statement adds: “In relation to current students, we consider each case on an individual basis, focusing on what is in the best interests of that individual, in full discussion with that student.
“Should the student decide that they would prefer to be in a mixed college if transitioning to male or if rejecting a binary gender category, the College would be fully supportive of a transfer.”
The decision has raised questions about the purpose of the College, which was founded to address gender imbalances at Cambridge University, which at the time had the lowest proportion of women undergraduates of any university in Britain.
Claudia Winkleman studied at Murray Edwards College, Cambridge Credit: BBC G ermaine Greer, a leading feminist and former lecturer at Newnham College, has described the decision as “ridiculous”.
“It’s a silly situation, and I’m sure that Murray Edwards will have their own reasons,” she told The Daily Telegraph.
“But it’s a difficult relationship, having a transgender person in an all-female environment. “If [Murray Edwards] really don’t believe that gender is binary, then they really shouldn’t be a single sex college. Their position is ridiculous. The only sane thing for them to do is to cease discriminating on the basis of assigned gender of any kind.
“There are plenty of women who have served their time in women’s colleges, who are pretty whiskery, but nobody did a DNA test on them. But they had to live women’s lives - with all the disabilities that that entails.”
Murray Edwards College D r Joanna Williams of the University of Kent said that the decision marked the “end of women-only spaces”.
“This college was set up several decades ago when things were very different for female students,” she said.
“If some women want to have a women-only space, if they choose to be there, they should have every right to do that.
“To then learn that you’re sharing your dormitory, your bathroom with someone who is biologically male is an infringement on your right to choose the right the educational environment you chose.”
Murray Edwards College used to be called New Hall A cademics from the college defended the move, saying it does not challenge the College’s single-sex status but is a recognition of the fact that "how we define women is changing".
Juliet Foster, a senior tutor at Murray Edwards, said: “Our position is very clear: we want to be open to all outstanding young women, and we felt that society is changing and there is greater understanding of the complexities surrounding gender.
“We felt that was therefore in line with our values to accept all women, including transgender people who identify as female."
Tilda Swinton studied at Murray Edwards College Credit: Rex Features D ame Barbara Stocking, President of Murray Edwards, added: “Society is changing and there is now a greater understanding of the complexities of gender.
"In order that we remain true to our mission of being open to all outstanding young women we recognise that it is right for anyone who identifies as female, regardless of their born gender, to be able to apply to study with us."
Kate Litman, women’s officer at Murray Edwards, said that students are “thrilled” with the change of policy. “We recognise many women still experience environments where their achievements are not recognised or their voice is not heard,” she said.
“Murray Edwards fosters an environment which celebrates women and encourages us to reach our potential, and it is absolutely right that all women should have the chance to study here, no matter what gender they were assigned at birth."
Celia Macleod, chair of the Gender Identity Research and Education Society (GIRES), a charity that supports people who are transgender or do not conform to a particular gender, said she welcomes the decision “to respect and support all gender diverse people”.
Murray Edwards, which was founded in 1954 and used to be called New Hall, is one of three all-women’s colleges at Cambridge University and is the first to make such a change to its admissions policy.
At the university’s other women-only colleges, Newnham and Lucy Cavendish, any application must be recognised under the Gender Recognition Act.

posts.text:
C helsea doctors are yet to put a timescale on Alvaro Morata’s return from injury but are hopeful it could be earlier than first feared.
Morata pulled out of the Spain squad for the games against Albania and Israel, with the Spanish Federation revealing the 24-year-old had undergone an MRI scan that revealed a grade two injury .
Medical experts claim that a grade two hamstring injury can sideline a player for anywhere between four to six weeks, but Chelsea doctors believe they can get him back earlier than that after initially assessing Morata on Tuesday.
Chelsea’s medical staff will continue to work with Morata over the next couple of days after which his return date will become clearer, but the Spaniard is clearly feeling optimistic.
Morata tweeted a picture of himself in Chelsea a training kit with the message: “I have no time to lose! Working hard towards recovery! Crystal Palace.”
Earlier tweet from @AlvaroMorata - now seemingly deleted. pic.twitter.com/S6lHuzudwu
— Dan Levene (@danlevene) October 3, 2017 B ut that tweet was quickly deleted and the Palace game on October 14 could still come too quickly for Morata. Chelsea also play Roma twice in the Champions League during October before Manchester United visit Stamford Bridge on November 5, so head coach Antonio Conte will not want to take any unnecessary risks.
After watching Morata limp off in the 35th minute of the defeat to Manchester City, Conte admitted he took a gamble over the fitness of Chelsea’s record signing by starting him. But the Italian had also suggested the Spaniard’s injury was not serious.
Which Premier League striker would you pick in your fantasy XI? L osing Morata for any length of time would be a considerable blow for Conte, as he once again demonstrated that he does not fully trust Michy Batshuayi by replacing his number nine with Willian against City.
Conte wanted to sign Fernando Llorente to act as a deputy to Morata, but Chelsea were beaten to his signature by Tottenham Hotspur.
