R epublic of Ireland assistant Roy Keane claimed physical contact is 'part of the game' and players worried about head injuries can 'play chess' instead, in the wake of Kevin Doyle's international retirement.
Doyle called time on his Ireland career aged 34 on Thursday due to persistent headaches caused by a series of concussions.
The former Reading striker described heading the ball as 'problematic' and his decision comes amid a campaign by The Telegraph for football’s governing bodies to fund research into the link between playing football and brain injuries.
Keane said: "If you're worried about the physical side of any sport - and you're wary of it - then play chess.
"It's part of the game whether it's hurling, American football...you see the rugby lads. It's part of the game.
Telegraph campaign - tackling football's dementia scandal "When you cross that line, there is an element of risk involved. I think the players who are playing now really, it wouldn't make any difference to them, they all want to be footballers."
D oyle's problems are a worrying development because he has played in an era when heavy leather footballs - often blamed in cases of historic injuries - are a thing of the past.
“I’m sad to announce that after listening to medical advice I will no further part in this season and will be retiring,” Doyle said in a statement. “This year it has been clear to me that heading the ball was becoming problematic, and causing me to have repeated headaches. Two concussions this season and numerous others over the years have made this more concerning."
The family of Jeff Astle - the former West Bromwich Albion player who died in 2002 with the symptoms of Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy - have campaigned for football's authorities to thoroughly research if players are disproportionately at risk of developing brain conditions.

Upon using servers from a different cloud services, some "overloaded", causing these crashes.
There's no timeline on when these issues will be fixed, but the team state that they're "not content with the status quo," referring to how players are having server issues. Expect updates and fixed in the future.

posts.author: Laura Suter
posts.title: Fidelity to overhaul investment charges across 400 funds
posts.text:
Laura Suter 3 October 2017 • 2:58pm 
A sset manager Fidelity is to overhaul its fund charges from next year in a move it says will align it better with investors. 
The Boston-headquartered fund giant, which oversees £233bn globally, announced that it will cut the basic charges applying to its fund range - but at the same time introduce a performance fee linked to success in beating the wider market. 
The change will apply only to "actively managed" portfolios, where fund managers are responsible for stock selection. 
Some of its actively-managed funds are among the most popular with private investors, including Fidelity UK Special Situations, formerly managed by celebrated stockpicker Anthony Bolton, and American Special Situations. 
Fidelity also manages "passive" or tracker funds whose makeup mirrors a stock market index, such as the FTSE 100. The range of passive funds will be expanded, said Fidelity, to meet growing investor demand for low-cost vehicles. 
The performance fee means that where a fund manager beats the relevant benchmark the firm takes a share of the profits, although the precise charge mechanism not been revealed. 
The performance fee will be taken even if the fund manager loses money. For example, if the benchmark falls by 10pc and the fund by 8pc it will be deemed to have "outperformed" and the fee will be triggered. 
However, if the fund manager delivers lower returns than the market it will hand back some of the costs, to compensate investors for some of their losses. 
Fidelity said both a cap and a floor would apply to the new charges, full details of which will be revealed at the start of next year. 
Investors will also not be forced to change to the new charging structure, and can remain on the existing fee system - although they will see a slight increase in the annual management charge. 
Fidelity is a major provider of investment funds to individual savers via Isas and pensions. Its announcement was not universally welcomed, however, with some warning that it would bewilder investors and others critical of the performance-based model. 
Darius McDermott, of Chealsea Financial Services, the broker, said: "It is hard to say this is the best thing since sliced bread, but what it will do is give more choice. 
"Choice is good, and Fidelity is trying to be innovative but so far this is as clear as mud and is going to lead to further confusion." 
Laith Khalaf, of Hargreaves Lansdown, Britain's biggest distributor of investment funds, said that performance fees have a chequered past. 
"Fees like this can work, but we have in the past seen performance fees that don’t act in clients' favour. A lot of it comes down to specifics of what the charges will be, what the benchmark is going to be, and how often the fee is calculated," he said. 
"It adds complexity and so makes fund comparisons more difficult for investors. Generally speaking we prefer simpler, lower annual management charges," Mr Khalaf said. investment fees calculator Who else charges performance fees? 
N eil Woodford's Patient Capital investment trust is one of the few large funds that charges a performance fee. 
However, it charges no annual management fee and must deliver annual performance of more than 10pc before it takes the performance fee. If it reaches this level the asset manager will take 15pc of the outperformance. 
Since launch in April 2015, the fund has failed to meet its performance target - and so no fee has been paid. 
The use by fund firms of performance fees surged between 2007 and 2010, after a ban on them by the regulators was lifted. 
Comprehensive research by data firm Lipper in 2012 found that funds charging a performance fee did not substantially outperform those that charged a flat fee. 
The data firm also discovered that a number of funds with performance fees had chosen to revert to a flat fee, or had closed.
